langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.l: Our Authors Pen, loves not to swim in blood,
He dips no Ink, from out black Acheron:
Nor sucks invention, from the depth of hell,
Nor crosseth Seas to get a foreign plot.
He taxes no Goddesses for foulest lust,
Nor doth disclose the secret scapes of Jove:
He rips not up the horrid maw of hell,
To show foul treasons hideous ugly face.
Nor doth he touch the falls of mighty Kings,
No ancient History, no Shepherd's love.
No statesman's life, no power of death he shows.
He only strives with mirth to please each one,
Since laughter is peculiar unto man.
and being sure, freely to speak can be no sin,
If honest words have honest construing.
Therefore to fly the least cause of offence,
He only finds but words, you find the sense:
Wherefore, if aught unto your ear taste tart,
Thank but yourselves , which good to ill convert,
Yet this he ought, hath strictly charged me say:
That he is a slave, and of a base condition,
That doth but draw it to suspicion.
That here he privately taxeth any man,
Since all the world yields vice to play upon .
What he intends, action shall make you know,
I should fore-stall the play, should I but show.

body.stage:
The Scene in London.
Enter Cupid.

sp.l: With feathered speed I pierced the Air,
The clouds asunder I did tear,
And thus with wings and bow come I
Newly from Jove's high Court in sky.
My mother kissed me at our parting,
But did charge me leave my darting,
And with a strict command did say,
Boy, on a Whirligig go play.
But such a round I will make him run,
As he shall end, where first begun.
My scourge-sticks shall be made of Darts,
Feathered with sighs of Lovers hearts.
Which made them fly with swiftest flight,
As lightning in tempestuous night.
My scourge itself , are golden tresses,
More richer far than chains of Esses.
With which I will make some dance a Jig,
More rounder yet than ever did Gig.
But time doth call me to be gone,
Yet first to all you lookers on,
Before I part, I thus much tell,
That Gods can go invisible.
And though you do not all times eye me,
Yet know at all times, I am by ye .
And be assured, and do not think
But that you stand full near the brink
Of my displeasure: which if ye win,
In love I will make ye sink or swim.
Thus farewell all, sit patient yet a while,
Lest Cupid make
yourselves, yourselves beguile.

body.stage: Enter the old Lord Nonsuch, Alderman Uenter, Sir Timothy Troublesome.

sp.speaker: Uenter.
sp.p: My Lord, you know yourself and I have long lived friends, and shall we now with firm affection knit? tie fast our friendship in our Of-springs love, convey our cares in one, our goods together, and our loves in them, and whiles the remnant of our aged days do last, let us doff all discontents, cast by the worlds encumbers, and leave the careful burthen of keeping that, was care enough to get upon the youthful hope of their more able strength.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: O Neighbour Venture, do you not know that to marry a Child, is but to mar a man? for he that cuts a tender twig in springing, both mars his length and spoils his growing: my son shall first see twenty years of age, before my condescent shall once be given to make him father of a son: Besides, your daughter yet is very young: and though in Women's sex it is always seen, desire to marriage rides always in post; yet in their Inn repentance is their host: the fault of this is always known to be, through foolish husbands: or such as are too young, for Children to their wives are like fruit half ripe, they yield no taste, nor give no sweet delight.

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.p: Behold, here comes my young Lord, the very model of yourself , the Vigour of your youth, and strength of all your future hopes.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: And he is welcome, what sudden gust (my Son) in haste hath blown thee hither, and made thee leave the Court, where so many earth-treading stars adorns the sky of state? or as the summers speckled flowery garment is spread about the seat of Majesty? what is the reason thou hast left this earthly Paradise, to visit us before our expectation?

sp.speaker: Young Lord.
sp.p:
My love dear Father (to your fair wife)
hath made my hours of absence from this place, seem tedious years, I could not but return from whence I came, as like to man, the which of clay was framed, at first did walk a while upon the earth, but in the end returned to dust; or like a River, which through the earth doth draw his life and spring from out the sea. Thus I that from you sprung, have run my course awhile, but now as to my sea, return to you again .

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: Thy answer with thy wisdom hath enriched thy welcome: dear friends, I pray you set your hands to this my deed.

sp.speaker: Uen.
sp.p: I do my Lord, with all devoted love.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And I which hate my wife his mistress: his welcome home, will breed my ill at home, I breed my horns as Children teeth, with sickness and with pain: and yet I will with as smooth a face as my wife will give me leave, make show of welcome. Sir, I much rejoice to see you, and doubt not, but ere long, you will come and see where my poor house doth stand.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Or else I were unworthy of your love if I neglect the visitation of so kind friends as yourself and my dear mistress.

Visitation! my wife is not sick, what visitation? It is I am ill, it is the horn plague I have , I am sure that is not Gods visitation, yet they are the Lords tokens, for he hath sent them me: but marry when you will, I will try and you be a Chandler, I will see if you will take your own tokens again : well , but in the mean time, I am marked for death, yet he will be in the pit before me. O that I should be a Cuckold! a creature of the last edition, and yet of the old print.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: O sir, What make you here , when there is a gallant Gentleman newly come from Court, talking within with my Lady.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p:
Yet more Courtiers, more Gallants, more Gentlemen?
now in a hundred thousand horned devils names, what makes he there? what is he gone to bed to your Lady? doth he Cuckold me in mine own house, in mine own chamber? nay in mine own Sheets? what he is come to visit her too , is he not, ha? But let me see, I have now found out a trick to know if my wife make me a Cuckold, I will geld myself , and then if my wife be with child, I shall be sure I am a Cuckold, that will do brave i'faith, God a mercy brain.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry that I cannot with that free scope of friendly entertainment, give welcome to your worth, because a jealous spirit haunts my husband, which doth disturb us all, this devil hath long vexed him, and he as long vexed me, and were I not composed of more than of an ordinary female spirit, the burthen of his wrongs would tire me quite.
Sir, this is my husband.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: I cry ye mercy sir, I did not see ye.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: A man would think ye saw me, for I am sure ye have hit me right enough.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: I pray sir be not angry, I have not any way offended you, nor would

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Nay, nay, though I be, ye may be friends again with me in spite of my teeth, for look ye sir: my wife and I are but one, and then though I fall out with you, you may fall in with her.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Sir, I come not to offend you nor

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Nay, nay, ye may, ye may i'faith, ye may, my wife is charitable, and would be glad by such a means to make us friends.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Sir, then know, I scorn my eyes should stand as witnesses unto your Ladies wrongs, and let you go unpunished: 'slight see a sweet Lady abused!

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p:
Sir you shall not touch him, husband you are to blame, your madness makes you much forget your manners, and wrongs my high birth, to make me the only cankered, and worm eaten branch that sprung out of my fathers
noble stock. No, no, know that the tree from which I grew, brought forth good fruit to all, not bad to you: but hence forth I will shake hands with mirth; and entertain a careless humour: for look ye sir, the Devil gives this jealousy to man, as nature doth a tail unto a Lion, which thinks in heat to beat away the Flies, when he doth most enrage himself with it: but come sir, will ye be my servant, my cipher, my shadow, or indeed anything ?

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Your shadow if you please, and you my substance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Aye , I warrant her with all her heart, and now must he do as all shadows do , when night comes, creeps into the substance.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Say he do, do ye hear husband, I here do vow before all the watchful guard of heaven, that I have lived as true unto thy bed, and chaste unto thy love, as ever was Turtle to her mate: but hence forth ceremonious custom shall not curb me of delight, let her be bridled by opinion, whose weak desires cannot break her reins: for my part, I will make you know my will is like a flint, smooth and cold, but being hardly strucken, sparkles forth fire even in the strikers eyes: I am ashamed that I have said thus much, yet I may lawfully speak, for why? come sir, will ye walk? the proverb says, give losers leave to talk.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O wages, wages, O honest wages! what other Gallants come to your Lady in my absence?

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Truly sir, sometimes there comes a proper young Gentleman one Master Woodlie.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Would lie! with whom would he lie good Wages?

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p:
Why with my Lady sir, if he could get her good will: but he is a Gentleman I can assure ye sir, for he walks always in boots, but in troth his gentility is something decaying, his boots are on their death-bed, for their
souls are upon parting, and I think he be a Soldier too, for his sword and his hangers are more worth than all his clothes, and a is a very proper man, for he is as tall as one of the Guard, and he will come sometimes and take my Lady by the hand, and pump for wit half an hour together.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: How dost mean, pump, ha!

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Why sir, thus he will take my Lady by the hand, and wring it half an hour together, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Is that pumping for wit?

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: O sir Aye , for he that wrings a fair Lady by the hand, and says nothing, doth but pump for wit, that is certain.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: A most witty exposition, of what years.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: Faith sir he is indeed a man of no ears, for he hath been on the Pillory.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: But what makes the crop eared stallion with my wife then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Alas nothing but lies with her, and she lies with him, would you have any more?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: More! no, too much by heaven, nay then it was past suspicion, past doubt, past jealousy; is not my hairs turned all to horns? am I not a monstrous and deformed Beast? my wife is a Goddess (though not Diana) she can transform: I branch wages, I brach, do I not? am not I a goodly screen for men to hang their hats upon.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: Why sir? ye are no Cuckold:

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No? no Cuckold? he lies with your Lady, and your Lady lies with him, yet I am no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why no, give me but attention, and with a word I will wipe away your horns.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: No, no, words are too weak to wipe them off, when deed have put them on.

sp.speaker: Wag,
sp.p: But hear me sir.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: with open ears to swallow comfort.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I met my Lady and he fast by the Garden wall, and asking for your jealous worship, they both replied you were not jealous, this spoke they both together: in this, you know they both did lie together, and yet made you no cuckold.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ha! meanest so?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Even so indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Nay, then I cry ye mercy wife, i'faith she yet may chance be honest.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O sir, very honest as a pretty Seamstress, or a poor waiting Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Well Wages, if I be a Cuckold

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why sir, what will ye do if ye be?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What will I do? I will make it known, for I will be a Citizen, and so be a Subject for Poets, and a slave to my own wife, therefore follow me Wages, I will do it .

body.stage: Exeunt omnes. Enter the Lady alone.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p:
O grief! how thou tormentest me, it dwells in mine eyes, feasts on my blood: swims in my tears, and lodges in my heart. O heaven! have I deserved this plague? O Husband! why shouldest thou use me thus? was not my behaviour unto thee as soft as Down, as smooth as polished crystal, Aye and my love as clear? was I not like a handmaid, even obedient to thy very thoughts? did not my nuptial duty like a shadow follow the very turning of thine eye? O ! thou once didst love me , but thy love was too hot, and like to self consuming fire, it burnt out, and how soon, it is turned to cold ashes, and therefore henceforth I will seem jealous of him: for since all endeavours fail, I will now try if Jealousy can drive out jealousy: and here is fit occasion for to work upon : Why how now Husband, wooing of another wife before my death, whence comes this? in my conscience it is a plague that Cupid hath lain upon me for sleeping
crosslegged in your absence. What, are ye grown as weary of your wife as of a foul shirt? must ye be changing?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Good madam be patient.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Patient! no, you are his patient, and he is your Physician, he ministers to ye (with a Morbus Gallicus take ye both) I pray forsooth let me be your Butler, and scrape your Trenchers, since I am already fain to live off your leavings.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Woman, art Jealous?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Aye .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Because you give me cause: but man are you jealous?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Aye .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: why?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Because thou givest me cause.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It is false.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: True, false, thou hast been false indeed, abused my bed, infected even my very blood, and made it grow to hard imposthumes on my brows: hast thou not wantonly, changed naked embracements with strangers? abused thy nuptial vow? hath not thy unsatiate womb, brought forth the bastardy of lust to call me father? but I will abandon thee, disclaim that, and hate ye both.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Do ye hear me sir, upon my conscience you do wrong your Lady.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: If I wrong her you will do her right, I bear a blow of yours, the which I never felt, you are like a man's Taylor that works with open shop for the Husband, but if you chance to do anything for the wife, you must do it inwards, inwards! you are a good workman, I must needs say it : you have fitted my wives body, how say ye wife, has he not?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not, but you can even in my sight cast amorous glances on others: you have forsook my bed, abhorred my presence and like a man past grace and shame, strut like a pimp before a wanton feather waging minx at hie noon: besides, did not I find thee kissing of thy Maid?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Did not I find thee in private conference with my horse-groom?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Didst thou not offer thy maid a new gown, for a nights lodging?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Didst not thou give a Diamond to the Butler?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Didst not thou send a bowed Angel to thy Laundress Daughter?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No it is false.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Yes, it is true, and then when I told thee of it , thou swarest it was out of charity, because the Wench was poor, her Father an honest man, and her Mother a painful woman: for these and these causes you were kind unto the Daughter, great whilst I was contented to believe, because I was unwilling, like a faint hearted Soldier to look of mine own wounds, until I saw thou daily woundest my love anew, and slewest thine one reputation.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Art mad?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: No, but a little Jealous like you, I will no longer maintain thy, sanguine sin, sooth lust with patience, nor in broken singing language flatter thy folly, as sweet heart do not wader: for I do love thee dear as doth a Goose her Gander: a Goose indeed for if aught but a Goose, I should have sought revenge for wrongs.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What art drunk?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No, for I have sufficient reason, too much knowledge, and sense enough to feel my wrongs: why should we women be slaves to your imperfections? have we not souls of one metal, are we not as free born as you? are we not all Adams Of-spring? did not you fall as well with him as we , and shall we be still kept down and you rise?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p:
Dost hear? ye are a sort of uncertain giddy wavering, tottering tumbling creatures, your affections are like yourselves , and yourselves like your affections, up and down , like the tucks on your Petticoats, which you let fall and take up as occasion serves: I have seen of your sex fall in love with a man, for wearing a handsome Rose on
his shoe: another fall into the passion of the heart, to see a man untie his point, to make water: a third fall into the shaking Ague for eating a body cherry with two stones, and yet you will be fellows, even with the very image of your maker: but wilt let me alone, and i'faith I will be quiet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Alone! faith no.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Then I will leave thee, since I know it is folly beyond madness, to make her pleasure cause of my sadness.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Believe it Lady, this was well done, and like a Lady of a hie birth: make your husband know his advancement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
O shadow, shadow, I would have you know I would not wrong him for all the seas drowned riches: for if my heart of blood should do it as he supposeth it doth, even that blood would like a traitor write my faults with blushing red upon my cheeks: but because I (as all women and Courtiers do ) love good clothes which his eyes wear, yet he upbraids me, swearing it is to please the multitude, and that I spread gay rags about me like a net to catch the hearts of strangers: if I go poor, then he swears I am beastly, with a loathed sluttishness: if I be sad, then I grieve he is so near: if merry, and with a modest wantonising kiss Embrace his Love, then are my twistings more dangerous than a Snakes, my lust more unsatiate than was Messalinas : Yet this from Jealousy doth always grow. What most they seek they loathest of all would know. But now to you dear Cousin, forgiveness let me ask, and pardon for my fained Jealousy, and take but thus much of my counsel. Marry not in haste , for she that takes the best of Husbands, puts but on a gold fetter, for husbands are but like to painted fruit, which promise much, but still deceives us when we come to touch: if you match with a Courtier, he will have a dozen mistresses at least and repent his marriage within four and
twenty hours at most , swearing a wife is fit for none but an old Justice or a country Gentleman. If ye marry a Citizen (though ye live never so honest) yet ye shall be sure to have a Cuckold to your Husband. If a Lawyer, the neatness of his Clarke will draw in question the good carriage of his wife. If a Merchant, he will be venturing abroad, when he might deal a great deal more safe at home: therefore come Cousin come, let us home, and this take of me , That amongst the best there is none good, all ill: she is married best that is : wedded to her will.

body.stage: Exeunt Omnes. Enter the Young Lord.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: They say Cupid is a boy, yet I have known him confute the opinion of all your Philosophers: for they hold every light thing tends directly up : but I think all know he makes every light wench, fall directly down . Well I am sure he hath knocked me with his bird bolt, for the which Venus give him correction; for I do already love a Lady of an incomparable delicacy, but she is another man's, and will shut her ears as close to keep out charms, as great men do their gates, to keep in alms. Yet I have no reason to despair, for I have kissed her, and the French proverb says, Fame baissee est demie ioyee, a woman kissed is half enjoyed: but I fear he means but the upper half.I have here a Letter must work a strange thing, and yet no miracle, it must make a Lady love her friend better than her own husband.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Save ye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O Wages! what Tennis-ball has fortune taken thee for: to toss thee thus into my way?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I hope ye will not strike me into any hazard of my life though.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But what is the news my Lad, what is the news? how doth Sir Timothie Troublesome, that jealous knight thy Master?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why sir, he doth with his wife like a cowardly Captain in a town of Garrison, fears every assault, trembles at the battery, and doubts most , lest the gates should be opened, and his enemy let in at midnight.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Now in the name of destiny who fears he ?

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: O sir next to yourself , none so much as your Courtier, for even with venomed Breath, he speaks of them: for saith he, have but a suite to one of them , and they are like Iourdaines, which though ye open the Floodgates of your bounty, and fill them to the very brim, yet they will always stand gaping for more.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But dost thou think his Lady honest?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: As woman's flesh may be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But she has been a Courtier, and therefore knowing most good, methinks she would commit least ill.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O sir, I will not but with sanctified and hallowed thoughts, touch Sinthias brightest beams, whom all eyes do adore, and hearts do worship: where purest chastity doth shine in spotless robes of splendent majesty, where nature emulating heaven to make her even as fair as she is virtuous, but yet I well could wish, you know that in the sky of Court are many stars, the which at midnight shoot and fall.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: True, through most of the twelve signs, for they shoot from their Husbands at Aries (which governs the head) and fall at Scorpio, and so indeed they shoot from top to tail: but honest Wages, will ye bind me to ye .

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I think sir it will not be so much for your health, as if I should keep you saleable.

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.p: I mean in courtesy good Wages.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: O! the very name of good Wages, will make a Serving-man do any courtesy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Then befriend me thus, deliver this Letter to your Ladies own hand, with as much secrecy as ye may, and
take this for your employment.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: As secret as she that sells complexion: none but the chambermaid shall know it.

body.stage:
Actus secundus
Scena prima. Enter Ladie alone with a Letter.

sp.p: Ye have your eyes like Sunglasses, catched the heat of my beauty, and cast it on your own heart, and doth your sighs like bellows, make it more inflamed? then spend your tears to quench it, for my chaste bloods honour shall never do it. Lust, it is like an over-swollen river, that breaks beyond all bounds: it is a Devil bred in the blood, nursed in desire, and like a Salamander lives in a continual fire: it sprouteth larger than the Ivy, which embraceth, twisteth and entangleth everyone within his reach, and makes no choice betwixt the goodliest Cedar and the stinkingest Elder: it is a foul usurper on the name of love, and reigns with greater domination than an Emperor: it is a very leprous Itch, it stains, and leaves a fouler spot upon the soul than tears can wash away: but my chaste thoughts shall watch mine honour: I will muster up my prayers to fight against temptation: shall I that have been a commander of myself , now prove a slave to sin? No, no, my mounting thoughts do soar too high a pitch to stoop to any strangers lure. Say that a peevish Fly entangled were within my never-shorn tresses, should I to save his life, cut and deform me of so rich an ornament? What though the Lord Nonsuch within my love entangled be , must my honour now be clipped to set him free? No, no, my saw is this and here he will come: wit of a Woman now assist me, O apron strings be now auspicious for here is my Husband, something I must do : I have it .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now fair mistress: this is strange to find you here alone:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not alone, but environed and accompanied.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: With many heart-biting thoughts, which like Acteons hounds have almost slain myself ; yet now my constancy shall prove a glass, in which yourself shall see your own errors: the Lord Nonsuch which you have long suspected, with unrebated edge of lust, hath always sought, (I must confess) to cut my very reputations throat, and this night

sp.speaker: Kni
sp.p: This night?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Aye this night, but hear me husband:

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No no, cuckold me, kill me with grief, do, do , and when I am dead marry him: he has made you a jointer already of Breech down : well wife well, I married you out of the Country, but you have learned the City fashions already: I am a Cuckold, I am, but ignorance that I was to marry thee so young, not being able scarce to put thine own apparel on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I was the fitter for a Husband, ye might then have been sure to have taken me a bed at all times.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: True, so might other men too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No, ye are deceived husband, other men never lie with a man's wife but when she is ready for them, but to the purpose: this night have I promised the Lord Nonsuch he shall enjoy my love, for which cause he will send a certain Pander before, for fear you stand a rock in his way, on which all his hopes will suffer shipwreck. Now this same Panderly Pylate shall be: by you bribed to stand sentinel, and give the watchword when he comes, that you may then punish him, either with death or fear.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O shallow and womanish invention, as if he would betray his master.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Tut money often times corrupts a good, disposition and makes a knave ride post to hell.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: But is this true? art honest indeed? come hither, dost love me, dost ? nay but tell me true, dost ?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Or else in hatred let me ever live.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Do not flatter me, I scarce believe thee, thou never kissest me but with such an affection, as a young wife doth an old husband, wringing her lips, and making a mouth as if she were taking a Potion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You distaste me much sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Dost not distastes me too sometimes, tell me true?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nothing but your Jealousy.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Well, prithee forgive me and let us go, but I will so swindge my Lord a whoreson otter, I will teach him fish in other men's ponds.

body.stage: Exeunt omnes. Enter Young Nonsuch and Wages.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Did you deliver my Letter?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: With secrecy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To herself ?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Her own hands.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Made she any answer?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Not any.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What other news then rides on the back of report?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why they say sir that mistress Correction the Midwife is turned hermaphrodite .

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why Hermaphrodite?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why sir, she is become a Midwife, for as your hermaphrodite hath two members the one to beget, the other to bring forth, so hath your Midwife two means, the one to bring you to beget, the other to bring it forth when it is begotten: and look you sir, here she appears upon her Q.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O prithee do thou board her as she passes by.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Who I board her? by this light I dare not.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Then I will: fairly met fair Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mist: Cor.
sp.p: Indeed forsooth I have been , by my truth I see he is a fine spoken man.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Where abouts is your house fair Lady?

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: Here fast by sir, not above a couple of stones cast off.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What Gentlewomen have ye at home?

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: O Master Wages, how do ye ? faith sir I have nobody at home but mistress Punckit, you know her well.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: what is she?

sp.speaker: Mi. C.
sp.p: Truly sir a very courteous Gentlewoman, and she loves to act in as clean linen as any Gentlewoman of her function about the town, and truly that is the reason that your sincere puritans cannot abide to wear a Surplice, because they say it is made of the same thing that your villainous sin is committed in, as your most profane holland.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Pray ye when was Master Wrestler of the Guard at your house?

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Who he? in troth Mistress Punckit cannot abide him, she swears he looks for all the world like the Dominical Letter in his red Coat: no Master Wages no, I can tell ye I have other manner of Guests come to my house than he: I have Pensioners, and Gentlemen Ushers, Knights, Captains and Commanders, Lieutenants, and Ancients, voluntary Gentlemen, Aye , and men that wear their cloaks lined through with velvet; I entertain no Mutton eating Innesa court men, no half lined cloak Citizens: nor flat capped Prentices, no, the best come to my house, Master Newcome the Courtier was there the other day, and truly he would have had some dealing with Mistress Punckit, but that he had no siller: and yet I must needs say it, he would have put her in very good obscurity, for he brought a Gentleman with him that would have give his word in a consumption of twenty pound, that he should have paid her at next meeting, and truly but that her trade stands so much upon present payment, and partly for mortalities sake, I think else she would have taken it, and yet before he went, I must needs say it, he showed himself like an honest Gentleman and a Courtier, for he left his Periwig in pawn: but had you seen how he looked, for all the world like an Ostriches egg, with a face drawn of the one side.

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.p: What other guests have ye?

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: There comes master Exhibition of the Inns a court very often, and Master Angel-taker the counsellor comes sometimes, but Mistress Punckit doth so jest with him, she swears to him as she hopes to be saved, and I may tell you sir, there is great hope of it , for truly she useth just and upright dealing with every man, but as I said, as she hopes to be saved, she would not marry him of all the men in the world.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No, why?

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Because she says that Lawyers are like Trumpeters, they sell their breath.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: She is a fool tell her, the Lawyers are the pillars of the Realm.

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: Yes forsooth so I said, but she said they were not only the Pillars but the Polars also, but I pray you sir of what profession are you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Faith of none Gentlewoman, only a young gallant as you see.

sp.speaker: Mi, Cor.
sp.p: A young Gallant, say you! i'faith, I will quickly try that by and by, do ye hear sir, do ye hear?

body.stage: Putting her hand to her purrsse.

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.p: What say you Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: I pray can you give me ten shillings for a piece of gold.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Yes that I can.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: O sir, O sir, I perceive you are no gallant i'faith, it would go deep my friend, I may tell you for a young gallant to change three groats for a shilling, and it were great fish, I may tell you too, to Angle for in a gallants great hose.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Hold mistress, spend that for my sake, and it shall not be long ere I will come and visit your house.

sp.speaker: Mist: Cor.
sp.p: I thank your worship, sir, I will be so bold as to take my deliverance out of your company.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: God be with you mistress Correction.

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: The like to you good Master Wages, but do you hear sir, I hope if your worship come to my house, if there be nobody at home but myself , though I am an old woman, yet I hope your worship will not despise age.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No, no, fear not that.

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: I thank ye heartily sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: With all my heart, Wages farewell, and bring but an answer of my letter; and I will be thy paymaster, not thy debtor.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Nuecome, Wages and Peg.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Indeed Lady I am a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: I understand so much by your name good Master Nuecome.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: And I am in grace too Lady, what my souls sweet secretary! you are fairly met indeed, how doth old Venture thy father?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O how perfumed your Courtiers phrases are: I left him in health sir.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O Aye , they speak in print I can tell you, and though it be a sin, To rob a man of his learning yet Courtiers are very seldom blamed For getting out of any men's books.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Yet I have known them steal out of them ere now.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay then you will make a Courtier a Thief:

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Aye , such a one as the good thief was.

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: Mass I wonder what Country man that good thief was?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O, he was my country man Lady, he was a borderer on North wales, I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Indeed and so I think, for not to flatter ye, many of your Country men have proved good thieves ever since: but I pray ye tell me, is it the fashion of your north wales, to suffer your beards to grow upwards thus, in spite of your nose?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p:
Yes Lady, all of us that are Courtiers: marry before when we were poor country fellows, we suffered our
beards carelessly to grow downward, and then they grow into our mouths in spite of our teeth, now you know hair is but excrement, and for mine own part, I had rather have my excrement in my nose, than in my teeth.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: I have heard most of your Country men are very active men.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O Lady, I have seen a youth of eighteen years in our Country, would have capered ye, thus high!

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: It has in a string then.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay, believe it, he would have done it with all his heart, but he could not.

sp.speaker: Peg
sp.p: They say too, most of your Country men are very valiant

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O Aye , they terrify their enemies with patience.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: O, we make the excellentest Soldiers in the world.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Aye , but they say, they cannot press a man to the wars though, In all your country.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: yes Knights:

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Why Knights?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: To save our Landed men at home.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: I have heard, most of ye are great Travellers.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Aye , for france Spain and England, and such neighbour countries, why I have been as far as Winchester myself .

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Indeed it is true, some of ye Travail so far abroad as ye come short home many times.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: I have heard ye are all Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Indeed I must confess Lady, we have few beggars, and those we have , we reward according, for if he be a lusty Knave, we give him a Lawyers alms, tell him of the statute: if a poor and decrepit fellow, we give him a Citizens wives charity, cry God help him, God help him.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: By your leave Master Nuecome, methinks you have a pretty lace on your band

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: A pretty slight court-lace, all show, all show.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What is this, a shirt that ye wear? else it is a mock beggar with strips.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: No, it is a shirt Lady.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What, did you make this Doublet new, or else ye new made it?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Yes I made it new Lady?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Believe me sir but the linings are old.

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: Fie, they are greasy.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: I think they are something sweaty indeed with hunting.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Hunting: why a man need not hunt far for game, what is this?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O, a Salamander Lady, it is a Salamander bred with the continual heat of sweating

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: What is your breech made all of one stuff Master Nuecome?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Pray why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Because methinks the soil changes here behind

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Aye , and so doth the air as well as the soil I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: What are these hose made of the newest fashion ye have at Court?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Faith Lady for mine own part I am no man's Ape, this is my fashion, and sometimes I stand in the presence with my cloak lined through, either with velvet or with Taffeta, if with Velvet, I let him hang on my shoulder, making the greatest show, carry my hat here .

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Now by the soul of chastity I swear, he is a proper man.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: If any man pass by and salute me, I salute him again , but if any Lady or Gentlewoman glide through the presence, and cast her eye on me , as commonly they use to do on men, that makes any show or glister as I always do .

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ye! always making clysters, I hold my life he is a Apothecary, do you never make no suppositories sir?

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p:
I keep my place of standing, carry my body
stiff and upright, blush not, am impudent enough, when perchance the heat of the Ladies affection makes her take a place of standing, either against the hangings or one of the bay windows, and there with a greedy eye feeds on my exteriors, which perceiving, I draw to her, kiss my hand, and accost her thus.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: I pray accost her anon sir, and let us stand close and trouble not true jealousy in the picture of Hieronimo, in a little volume.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: See, see how he looks, do you not perceive his heart beat hither?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Aye , for all the world like the Denmarke Drummer.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Peace, hear what he says.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p:
Forgiveness wife: O how have I wronged thee, O who would abuse your sex, which truly knows ye? O women were we not born of ye? should we not then honour you? nursed by ye, and not regard ye? begotten on ye, and not love ye ? made for ye, and not seek ye? and since we were made before ye , should we not love and admire ye as the last? and therefore perfectest work of nature, Man was made when nature was but an apprentice, but woman when she was a skilful Mistress of her Art, therefore cursed is he that doth not admire those Paragons, those Models of heaven, Angels on earth Goddesses in shape: by their loves we live in double breath, even in our Offspring after death. Are not all Vices masculine, and Virtues feminine? are not the Muses the loves of the learned? do not all noble spirits follow the Graces because they are women, there is but one Phoenix and she is a female: Is not the Princes and founders of good arts Minerua, born of the brain of highest Jove, a woman? have not these women, the face of love the tongue of persuasion, the body of delight? O divine perfectioned, women, whose praises no tongue can full express, for that the matter doth exceed
the labour, O if to be a Woman be so excellent, what is it then to be a woman enriched by nature, made excellent by education, noble by birth, chaste by virtue, adorned by beauty: A fair woman which is the ornament of heaven, the grace of earth, the joy of life and the delight of all sense, even the very summum bonum of man's life.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: O monstrous heresy, he will be damned for that error.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: Nay, let him alone, for he had like to been burnt for that opinion ere now, had not a friend of mine plucked the fire from the stake.

sp.speaker: Nuc:
sp.p: Come, let us break out upon him.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: O no good sir, though it be a thing much given to your name, yet let not us break out, let us not show such childish parts.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Save ye Knight.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And bless ye Lady, O sirrah, are you there? come ye hither, what is that strange Lady there?

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: I think it be mistress Babee sir, master Nuecome's Mistress, for she looks like an Northern Lass, made of a strange fashion, something like a Lute, all belly to the neck.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: So, like a Lute, and you like a skilful musician have been fingering it.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: How does your good Lady Knight, how doth she?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Well I praise Him, and I adore my stars, she hath no acquaintance with such a female fly as you are.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: What means he by that?

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: Why I think he means you are but a light housewife, but come let us leave him.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Light Housewife, hang him dogged Cynic.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Farewell Knight.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Forgiveness wife.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now the plague of Egypt light upon you all, Lice devour ye: come ye hither sirrah, what is the cause you keep such villainous company?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
I keep their company most sir for good victuals,
For you keep such a villainous house, as if it were always Easter eve, we still hope for better: and you know your Cook is gone already sir, For fear he should forget his occupation with you. Besides sir, if any man come to your house to dinner though he hop upon one leg, yet every man saith he comes to fast, and for mine own part sir, you have given me nothing since I came unto you.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O thou pampered Jade! what wouldst thou have ? what wouldst thou feed on Quailes? art thou not Fat? is not thy neck brawn, thy leg calf? thy head beef, and yet thou wants meat.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: No sir, but I would willingly have some wages.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Well, I will think on it , and so go call your mistress.

sp.speaker: VVag:
sp.p: Look you sir, here she comes without calling.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Save your honesty then, and be gone without bid ding.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: I vanish sir.

sp.speaker: Kn:
sp.p: Do so: O my sweet wife, my selected spouse, the very vessel of chastity, filled to the very brim with Hymen zeal and nuptial duty: how have I abused thee? but I have washed repentance even in tears, and in thy absence I have dedicated sacred sighs unto thee to appease thy wrath: therefore tell me sweet wife, when comes this pander, when comes he?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I muse he stays so long, he should have been by promise here an hour since, and look here he comes?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: O you are welcome Sir, welcome i'faith, but when comes your Lord? is he at hand, will he come?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My Lord sir, what Lord?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Nay, come, come, make not the matter strange man, my wife hath told me all, you are an honest man, hold, hold, will ye but be friend me now, and watch another door unto my house, and give me notice when he comes, while I watch this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O now I see the trick of it , his wife hath gulled him with a lie and made him believe I am but a pore serving-man only to enjoy my love: O kind woman! O sweet Lady! nay now I see she loves me.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O excellent wife, how true she told me, what a beast have I been still to wrong her with suspect.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Faith sir I see ye are a very worthy Gentleman, and for mine own part I shall be glad to do you any pleasure, for to tell you true, I think my Lord means to Cuckold you indeed.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Why that is well said, hold here is one Angel more, and go but with my wife, she will show you the other door while I watch this: and if he come, knock him down , kill him, and lay the fault on me, I will please you for your pains, look, here is a club will hold.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Give me, give me, come.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Go wife, go with him, see he stand stiffly to it , and if occasion serve.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I warrant ye husband, fear it not, but I will do my part.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Why that is well said, and if he come to this door, I will teach him come to tie his mare in my ground, but what a slave have I been still thus to suspect my wife, I could never feel any horns I had, and yet I know my skull is so thin that if my wife should a Cuckold me with the least thing in the world, yet my horns would have grown through now am I for my Lord.

body.stage: Enter Lord and the Lady at an other dore.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Now fair mistress, this far through the mouth of danger am I come and made my passage even through her life-devouring Jaws to feast mine eyes upon this beauty, which makes me think all danger is but a sport, so you receive and wrap me in your loves embracements, and take hold of this fair occasion, for well you know your Husbands Jealousy will turn this proffered time like fortunes wheel, and drown our fairest hopes even in despair, if you be tedious in our loves effects, and therefore since your wit hath safely plotted my arrival here , proceed even to the utmost lists of my desire, and make me happy in the fruition of your long desired love.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O my Lord, shall a smile, a good word, a little kind behaviour, or the title of dear servant, make your hopes to swell into so great a sea of lust, as presently to ever-flow and drown the honour of your Mistress? O my Lord no, your judgment much deceives you of my disposition: besides, I sent not for ye , it was your lewd unbridled will, that made you thus come gallop hither: yet by my means I must confess as yet you are unknown, and in some sort I glad your being here; only to make you know, that neither fairest occasions nor greatest persuasions shall ever make me violate my faith to him I owe my love; No my Lord I know I durst to trust myself against the most of opportunity and strength of all temptation, and though my husband watch you at the door, yet know within, my conscience watcheth me though he be blinded with a trick, yet the clear all-light, givers eyes do see: therefore good my Lord be gone, you see my husband is wilful bent, and if he chance to know you, I much doubt your safety.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But is this my pains requital and my loves reward?

sp.speaker: Kni,
sp.p: Alas my Lord, what would you have ? my love is not mine own .

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well, farewell Lady, you may repent this yet ere log: yet peace fond breath, lest threats my plots beguile: vengeance intended policy, must smile.

body.stage: Exeunt Lord and Lady Enter Lord.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Are ye going sir, are ye going, what will not your Lord come?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I think not sir, his hour is past long since, some other business hinders him.

sp.speaker: Kni
sp.p: Gods my passion, what do I see, this is he , I see his chain: nay but look you sir, when will you come again ? by this light I see his signet ring.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Assure yourself sir, I will bring you notice before my Lord come.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p:
Nay, but will you sure? shall I trust to you? for look ye sir, and if you should not come, pray ye stay a little,
methinks your band is torn.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: It is no matter no matter.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No, it is not now I see it , by this hand it is he, it is he, what should I do , now if I should strike him, he would be too hard for me, for he is better armed than I.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well sir I will take my leave of you, till your occasion shall need my presence.

sp.speaker: Kni
sp.p: Fare ye well sir, I hope that shall be never : but have not I spun a fair thread think you, to be a very Bawd, an arrant wittol, to give them opportunity, put them together, Nay hold the door the whilst this is my wives plot, by which I have sailed to Cuckolds haven yet my sail was but a smock, which she herself hoist up alas, alas, Gentlemen do you not know the Philosopher saith this world is but a stage: hodie mihi, cras tibi: it is my part today , it may be some of yours tomorrow why it is but matrimonial chance, we that are Cuckolds should be wisest men, for no men else do know their ends, but we know ours, for we are forked at both O thou powerful and celestial Jove! strike down from heaven some congealed bolts of thunder, that it may pierce the womb of earth, and through it send thy lightning flames to make hell hotter than it is, or with Egyptian damps and rotten jaws renovate thy eating plague of life, dissolve nature, consume earth, destroy hell, and damned woman I beseech thee into a deeper dungeon than the Devil. They fill men with diseases, and give the wane-eyed Sun of Heaven cause to smile to see our pains: shall the gaping of graves, the screeching of Ghosts, and cries of damned souls, yet longer be deferred? shall time incorporate with sin, and beget more mischief? shall hell be better furnished with women than with Devils? infernal: Lucifer will muster up his female souls against thy deity, unless thou do abridge the course of sin by cutting off the increase of women, and then we shall have no more cuckolds. Come ye hither wife, come ye hither, pray ye tell me one thing true.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: True: why husband, I will lie for no man's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Yes, for his pleasure that is gone.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For his pleasure, why for his pleasure?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Because you are a Punk wife, a punk.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now Jove bless me.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: You are a Cockatrice wife, a cockatrice:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now heavens defend me.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: You are a whore wife, a whore.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir, the man is mad.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Aye , horn mad, ah thou vile perfidious, detestable, lascivious, unsatiable, Luxurious and abominable strumpet, was it not enough to be an Acteon, a cornuto, a cuckold, but to make me a Bawd, a Pimp, a Pander?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What Pimp? what Pander?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: What Pimp? what Pander? why was not this the Lord Nonsuch? did I not see his chain, nay prithee say it was not he, nay swear it too: over shoes over boots, since ye have waded to the belly in sin, nay now go deeper even to the breast and heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray ye hear me husband.

sp.speaker: Kni,
sp.p: What vile excuses canst make, how canst thou hide thy lust? wouldst wrap thy sin in perjury to muscle up thy villainy?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay good Husband for pity sake hear me.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Talk not of pity, pity is deaf and cannot hear the poor man's cry, much less a strumpets.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For charity hear me.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Charity is frozen and benumbed with cold, it cannot help thee, dost kneel? dost kneel? to the heavens not to me yet they look thy heart should stoop, and not the knee. Dost weep dost? rise, rise thou strumpet, go out of my sight, in, in.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I go, Yet this my comfort, in the gall of life, Suspicion never wronged a truer wife.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ho, Wages!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Come hither Wages, my old resolution is come on me again , and it shall make me do much, for I will geld myself .

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Alas sir that is the only way to make you do little.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Therefore go fetch me the Operator.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What is he sir?

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: The stone-Cutter.

sp.speaker: Wag
sp.p: O you mean the Sow-gelder.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O! he is an excellent fellow, he takes away the cause of a man's beastly desires.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Aye , and of their manly performance too.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: He makes a man not care a rush for a woman.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: No, nor a Woman care a straw for a man.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Doth not such a fellow deserve commendations?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Yes as a hangman doth, for cutting off the traitors That makes the flesh rebel.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Wages I do now more doubt my wives honesty than ever , therefore I will make him the touchstone of her reputation.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Faith sir ye might get easier touchstones than he a great deal, there is many a Goldsmiths wife in Cheapside could help you to a better.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: He deserves much praise.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Aye , as your cockatrice doth for the dismembering of men.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: If she be a punckit I will not be divorced.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Why should ye? why ye cannot keep more Gentleman like company: besides, your punk: is like your politician, for they both consume themselves , for the common people. And your punk of the two, is the better member,
for she like a candle to light others, burns herself .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Well wages, come follow me, for I am resolved to try my wives honesty.

body.stage: Actus Ter. scena prima Enter young Nonsuch like a begging Soldier.

sp.speaker: Young Lord.
sp.l: Venus lay where Mars had found her,
And in warlike arms he bound her,
Cupid cried, and Vulcan spied:
And thereon threw the Sciclops,
But his horn, begat his scorn,
With all the little Gods mocks.
sp.p: Now some honest Gentleman pass by that I might sell him the maidenhead of my occupation for a half penny mass, here he comes, he shall have it , ye faith.

Worshipful Gentleman, look with your eye, and pity with your heart the distress of a martial man, I have been a man in my days, and acquainted with better fortunes than I now see: time hath been I have borne arms, but now one is gone, and I can no longer write Gentleman: wherefore if you please to bestow but one poor thistle of your bounty to prick the blister of my poverty, it would set my slender fortunes a float, where they now lie beating on the goodwins of famine, I am none of these Ludgations that beg for fourscore and ten poor men: my suite is only for myself .

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Whom hast thou served friend?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: First I served in Ireland, then in Holland, Braband, Zealand, Gelderland, Friesland, and most of the seventeen Provinces, I was at the siege of Bargon up sone, carried a pike at the entrance of Sluice, and was hurt in the groin entering the breach.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Who was thy Captain?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I served under the command of Captain pipe.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Who, captain Gregorie Pipe?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No sir, Captain Tobacco Pipe.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: O, I know him well indeed, he is on the English nation, hath much employments.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I can assure your worship sir, I have seen him in very hot service, and when some of us his followers have smoked for it too: wherefore I beseech you sir, bestow something on me, for the knowledge you had of my good Captain.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Go to sirrah, I fear ye are a counterfeit Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How Rogue sir: though none of fortunes favourites, nor great men's minions, yet perchance as good a man as yourself : 'swounds Rogue!

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Nay be not angry good friend for i'faith I love a Soldier with all my heart, for indeed I have a Cousin is one, would give thee something, but i'faith I have no siller, yet I give thee eighteen pence in conceit, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: Well sir, in conceit I thank ye then.
Ye Wages, come ye after like a Clog to the heels of the old Ape your Master?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Wages, how many pounds go to a stone of beef?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Eight sir.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Then I am lighter by sixteen pound now than I was, I may now lie with any Lady in Europe for any hurt I can do her.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: True sir, or good either.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: I can cuckold no man,

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: Yet any man may cuckold you.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: What is he Wages?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Some poor Soldier sir, lately come out of the low countries.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I must not now beg lame, for fear I lose his service
by it: I beseech ye good black Captain bestow something of a poor Soldier, that hath served his Prince both by Sea and land: if you bestow but one poor penny of your liberality, when the wheel of fate, turns, if the bitter frosts of poverty do not in the mean time nip my fortunes in the blossoms, I doubt not but to reciprocate your courtesy.

sp.speaker: UUag
sp.p: Hyda, what an excellent fellow this would make to dwell in the exchange, how the Rogue prates?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What art a Soldier?

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.p: I have been one some few years.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Why then thou art a Gentleman by profession, and it is a shame for a Gentleman to beg.

sp.speaker: Lor:
sp.p: So I think, for I have Gentleman-like qualities enough: for I had rather drink drunk to purge, then take Physic: but will you give me anything sir?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: No sir my master doth not use to give Gentlemen money, for fear of disgracing them.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O, I cry you mercy good Master Mustard-Pot.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Mustard pot! Gods light, mustard Pot! and why Mustard pot?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Because thou art a sauce-box.

sp.speaker: VVag:
sp.p: Sauce-box?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Go to, be quiet Wages.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But will ye give me anything sir?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No not a penny.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Come then sir, will ye walk a turn or two ?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Walk with thee, why, art not lousy?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I need not, I hate change enough, for I have two pair of shoes.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Wert never in better fashion?

sp.speaker: Lor,
sp.p: Yes, I have borne the badge of honour in my days.

sp.speaker: Wag
sp.p: Aye, he hath been some Nobleman's Footman sure.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Was thy Father an Alchemist that thou art so poor?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why do you not know poverty hath a Gentleman Ushers place, it goes bere before death.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Thy name,

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Slack.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Of what Religion art

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Faith I am yet clean paper, ye may write on me what ye will, either Puritan or Protestant.

sp.speaker: Kni,
sp.p: Wilt thou serve me?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: So you will give me wages.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Yes that I will, and thou shalt wear my livery too, I will give it thee, thou shalt not buy it thyself .

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O Mistress Correction! how do you?

sp.speaker: Mist: Cor.
sp.p: I thank ye good Master Wages, and how doth that goodly Gelding your Master?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why Gelding?

sp.speaker: Mist: Cor.
sp.p: Because he hath both abused and accused one of the most virtuous Ladies that ever frizzled her hair.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Peace, speak soft, that is he.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co:
sp.p: Is that he?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Now by my troth I am glad to see your worship in good health, and how doth your good Worship: Lord you look ill, a body may see what grief will do : O had you had a good wife, your worship would look twenty years younger than you do, it is even pity of her life that would wrong such a sweet man: what an excellent complexion your beard is off, and by my troth he keeps his colour very well.
What now you saucy Companion you, what ail you trow?

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: You had an ill Midwife Mistress, she hath not closed your mold well behind.

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: Marry come up Jack an Apes father in law, what can you tell?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I felt it by giving my hand to bid it farewell.

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: O sir, that is sign ye are a clown, if ye had been a Gentleman ye would have kissed it, and have taken your leave on it , I pray master Wages what is this fellow?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: A new man of my masters, and I can assure you a tall Soldier too.

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: A tall Soldier say you? So methinks , his clothes have been in shroud services, for they are very dangerously wounded. Sir, and like your worship, this that you have entertained is no man, it is some Scarecrow, and you have done very ill to take him away: the Crows will eat up the Corn now out of all measure, pray God we have not a dear year after it.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I know your husband well Mistress Correction, and Mistress Punckit too, I hear she keeps her bed much, what is she not in health?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: have you such a Gentlewoman lies at your house?

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, a younger Brothers Daughter, a kins-woman of my Husbands.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: It seems he hath been acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Who he ? no sir, she scorns to speak with him, unless it were by an Attorney.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Pray ye how doth your Husband good Mistress Correction.

sp.speaker: Mist: Cor.
sp.p: The better your asking good Master Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Indeed her Husband is a very honest painful man sir.

sp.speaker: Mist. Cor.
sp.p: O master Wages, no, no, master Wages, you are deceived in him, there is never a morning but I am ready and abroad, an hour before he is up : and when he is up , as I am a living woman I can make him do nothing for my life.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No, doth he not study?

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Yes, like the Clarke of a great man's kitchen, what meat he shall have for dinner.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Believe it but he is a good Scholar though, O he
hath a passing head of his own .

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Hath he, Aye he hath indeed, if ye knew all , and I can tell ye he may thank me for it too, for he went to school to time in my first husbands time

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: Pray ye what was your first husband

sp.speaker: Mi, Cor.
sp.p: Master. Seldom the preacher if it like your worship, he preached in two of his benefices in one day, and sure it was the death of him, he never joyed himself after he so overstrained his voice.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And then you married this man?

sp.speaker: Mi. C.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, and truly afterwards bought him a benefice, but he hath sold it again, and I may tell you though I am no Lady, yet he is called sir Iohn every word, and for all this now he makes no more account of me than your man Master. Wages doth of an old shoe-clout which he never thinks off, but when he needs, and if he cannot find it, why any other thing serves his turn, and so he deals by me, and truly Master. Wages I may tell you, I mean to put him away.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Away! why ye cannot put him away for this.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Yes I warrant ye, if you can find in your heart to love and marry me, let me alone for that I will keep ye like a man all days of your life: besides, if the stones of the street in the city should be too hot, for ye, and that ye dare not walk on them for fear the wicked vanities of the world should catch hold of ye, as they have done to the utter overthrow and undoing of many a good man, yet I can get my living in the Suburbs, and what trade so ever go down, I doubt not but mine will hold up as long as the kingdom yields either soldiers or younger brothers, which wants maintenance to keep wives of their own No Master. Wages, my trade is a sweet trade, little doth anybody know what comings in I have daily, I keep three as good feather-beds going winter and summer, as any sinner in the suburbs: besides, I warrant ye, I get above twenty pound a year in Rhenish wine, at the second hand.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Well , ask my Master. if he be willing, ye shall find me forward

sp.speaker: M: C.
sp.p: And that is as much as any woman can ask truly: if it please your worship I have a suite to you.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What is it Mistress Correction for you are very like to speed?

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: That I may have your good will to marry Master. Wages.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Why you have a husband alive?

sp.speaker: Mi. C.
sp.p: Aye , but I can be divorced from him, and like your worship for three several causes which I know well enough, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: If he be willing, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mist: Cor.
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: His fellow Wages, pray a word we, dost mean to have her?

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Aye .

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, I warrant thee a sound piece of her.

sp.speaker: VVag:
sp.p: A piece, why a piece? didst thou ever shoot in her?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Who I, no: she recoils too much in the discharging for me to meddle with, but dost hear, put her away again as soon as thou canst: if thou keep her long, if she prove not like a commodity of wood, and stink in thy hands then hang me.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Well Mistress Correction, I could wish you go about this your affairs as soon as you may, and Slack, and Wages do you two follow me.

body.stage: Exeunt 3. at one doore, and the Baud at the other. Enter Peg and Nan.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Now by my chaste thoughts which I was mother of at nine years old, I here swear, never to be in love: yet Master Nuecome the Courtier thinks with the wearing of a neat boot, and a clean band, to catch my love napping as Morse catched this Mare, but Venus be my good speed, and Cupid send me good luck, for my heart is very light, and I fear it is but like a Candle, burnt into the Socket, which lightens a little before it goes out.

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: I most fear it is like lightning before thunder, I pray have a care ye hold fast.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Come, thou hast such a running wit, it is like an Irish foot boy, I fear it will rob thee of all thy friends, and then run from thee and leave thee. But I pray thee tell me one thing,

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: I will if it be a good thing?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Hast thou thy Maiden head yet?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: My maidenhead! faith Aye .

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Come, prithee do not lie, for they say it is lost lying, and by the strength of my little virtue, I wonder (for mine own part) to see how this foolish virginity is esteemed when there is such danger in the keeping it, for who doth not know that the barren womb is cursed? and all know virgins have no children: besides, Women shall be saved by the bearing of Children, how thinkst thou, are they?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Nay, I cannot tell, you were best try.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Indeed they say it is good to try before one trust.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: But I pray thee tell me one thing now,

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: The reason why thou art come run away from thy Father, considering the foreman of your Shop, methought was a good handsome fellow.

sp.speaker: Nan
sp.p: It is true, so he was but he had no leisure to keep me company a work days for crying what do you lack, and a Holy days he would be at stool-ball amongst the boys when I had most need of him: but to tell thee the true cause of my coming away; I should have married a young unthrifty Lord, one that will give his very soul to a fair woman, and faith sometimes though she be never so foul, yet he will lend her his body: he had never a hair on his beard this three or four year, but might have been an utter barrister, for they have moulted all five or six times: he is like death, he spares none, young nor old, rich nor poor, fair nor foul, he takes all.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Well Nan well, thou art happy, thou wert born under a good Planet, thou hast store of suitors, but prithee look, is there none here is our counsel?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: No none, speak boldly lass.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p:
I think an ill star reigned when I was born, I cannot have as much as suitor, this Master Nuecome that you forsooth so much scorn: I could find in my heart to pray nine times to the Moon, and fast three Saint Annes eves, so that I might be sure to have him to my
husband.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Aye , thou wouldst have him dreaming but not waking I am sure.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: Not waking! yea and a bed too, for here I vow even by the chastest thoughts that ever was nursed within Dianaes breast and by those purple drops chaste Lucres spilt, and by the unstained colour of a maidens blush, that I will prove as true unto his bed, as ever did she that did Vlisses wed.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay, since I have refused a Lord, by this light I scorn to marry any under the degree of a Knight.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, I would not have a Knight if I might, for there are so many, as they are forgotten what they be.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay! then I see you are deceived, why woman, they have most of them taken an order that they will never be forgotten, for they have booked themselves down a purpose, I know above three and twenty in one Mercers books in Cheap side: then judge thou how many are in all their books, and there is that will be a witness I warrant you too after ages, what their forefathers have been .

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: Aye , but that is but their faults, yet you know their calling is honourable though.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Faith thou sayst true, I must needs sayst Knighthood is like marriage now a days, which though it be honourable amongst all men; yet is beggary with a great many: but come shall us go to dinner and see what stomach I have to my victuals, for i'faith I have none to a husband: I would not taste a morsel of a man for any money.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: O that is because thou art not hungry.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It is true indeed, a little bit would fill my belly.

body.stage:
Exeunt omnes.
Enter Lady and Slacke after her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O my unkind husband, why dost reject me ? if not on thee, where should I fix my love to have reward?

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Here where you are, in dear and hie regard.

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: Alas thou art a man of mean condition.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.l: Your love to me, will breed the less suspicion.
Fortune denies me wealth: all ill upon her,
Yet I have courage to defend your honour,
Madam, you reason have to be unjust:
A wicked husband makes an unkind wife.
Men brag, that women weaker creatures be,
Yet you must suffer all gross Injury,
with silence too, and lowliness of spirit,
And then forsooth a good wives name your merit.
A goodly purchase sure to be a slave,
Unto a slave, till you go to the grave.
Eve had a soul as well as Adam,
All souls are masculine, hold freedom Madam.
If strength of body make the noblest creature,
Why should not Lions be the Kings of nature?
The strongest creatures governed are by sense,
And there thy soul hath little residence.
Philosophers say, the Element of fire,
Is active, purest, aptest to aspire:
Of which you women have the lesser portion,
Which makes your brains beget cold Notion.
I grant that Adam was created so,
But since his fall, all thinks do backward go.
Now active heart, gets murther, theft and rapine:
It is thy chariot which all vice doth ride in.
Against whose ills women could temper spurns,
Give me the heart which warms not that which burns.
O hateful is the state you now do hold,
Worse than the slave, that is for money sold.
For you must money give to buy your evils,
and bind yourselves , to some incarnate devils.
Be but chief steward in their drudgery,
Bring forth their brats with your lives jeopardy.
Scarce dare you give, an old sleeve from your arm,
But they cry out, you are under Covert baron.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Presumptuous slave whose flesh upon thy bone,
Thy Master just, may challenge as his own :
Which by the dead scrapes from his trencher got,
Is quickened now, to cut thy givers throat:
Thou venomed Snake, frozen with beggary,
Now being thawed by thy masters bounty.
Wouldst sting the bosom that did revive thee,
and like a viper gnaw, who first conceived thee.
Full argument of a servile spirit,
For noble hearts will gratify each merit.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Yea, are ye vanished?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why how now fellow Slack, what is she gone?

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: 'Slife what should I do now to stop this slaves venomed breath, for fear it infect my reputation with my new master? this time was ill taken, yet something? I must do : fellow Wages, how long hast thou been here ?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Ever since fortune denied thee wealth: all ill upon her: but thou hast courage to defend her honour.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: 'Slight he hath heard all. Why man it was my master set me only to try her.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Nay, like enough, for I see he would willingly prove an accessory to the stealing of his own goods.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True, and look here he comes, but I pray thee say nothing, let me tell him of it.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Who I? not a word, my mouth is as close as a falconers pouch, or a country wenches placket.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: She would never cuckold me, but that she hath some reason for it

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
True sir, there is nothing done, but there is reason for it, (if a man could find it) for what is the reason your Citizens wives continually wear hats, but to show the desire they have always to be covered. Or why do your Seamsters spend their time in pricking, and your Ladies in poking of ruffs; but only to show they do as they would be done unto ? or why do your Inns of court men lie with his Laundress in a long vacation, but because he hath no money to go abroad? Or why do your old judges widows
always marry young Gentlemen, but to show that they love execution better than judgment.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O, but I wonder much she would not give me leave to make my first child myself .

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Foe: she knew you were but a prentice to the occupation, and commonly Prentices spoil their first work, and being unskilful, she was loath you should practise in a good Shop, and therefore she befriended you, because she would have it well done: she begat a better workman to do it for you. For what is the reason the younger brothers (according to the old wives tails) always proved the wisest men, but because the Fathers grew more skilful at last than they were at the first? but I think your wives eldest Son will prove an excellent fellow, because she had the help of so many in the making of it. For commonly if one have a thing to be done, as a conveyance to be drawn, or a case in the law to be argued, a man would have the help of as many good Lawyers as he could get: now this case of making of children, and a case in the law, is something like, for as one Lawyer takes his fee, and deals in it , another Lawyer comes and argues the case more profoundly: but in the end when all is done, leaves it to be tried by the Jury, in whom the right is, and so must you: when they and you and all have done your best, yet in the end, must leave it to be tried by your wife, whose the child is, for a woman's knowledge in this case, is better than twelve men's.

sp.speaker: Kn:
sp.p: O Slack, I hate her worse than the worst sin that is.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: And I pray which sin do you most hate?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: That which is most like her, which if thou wilt repeat

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I will tell their conditions.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: And Aye , which is most like her.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: Then the first is pride.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I would have that sin burnt for a witch, it changes men into so many shapes.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: The next is murther.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: O! that is a thirsty sin, for naught can quench it but blood.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What is Theft?

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: Faith the greatest fault that I can find in that is, it cozens the Scriveners, for it borrows money without giving any obligation.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Covetousness.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O! that is an excellent sin, for to deal with, he that hath a loose belly, for it will bind any man for ten groats.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What is sloth then?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Faith Sloth is a good Maidenly Green sickness sin.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: But lechery my Lady?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O that is the suckingest sin that a man can be acquainted withal, it cannot endure to be in company, it creeps into corners, and hides itself in the dark still.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: What sayst then to drunkenness?

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: O that is a most gentleman like sin, it scorns to be beholding for what it receives in a man's house, it commonly leaves it again at his door.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Nay, then lechery scorns to be beholding too, for I have known what it hath received in a man's house, it hath sent home again nine months after, and lain at his door, and therefore the more Gentleman like sin a great deal, because it takes the longer time of repayment, but I pray sir now, which of all this is most like your wife.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Murther, for naught can quench her thirst of lust, but now I soon shall find her villainy, praised be my vigilant care: which if I do espy, I will turn her off.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Alas, alas sir, you have no reason to be angry, much less to be divorced, although she do transgress, are you not cut? have ye not given her cause, is it not out of mere necessity she doth it? therefore if you follow my counsel, make her amends with kindness,
and put not her away.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Believe me he speaks wisely, and good counsel, like a Lady, is to be embraced.

sp.speaker: Slac,
sp.p: Not put her away, and if she wrong him. If he do not, I say he is one of the arrantest blocks that ever man spurned on: why is he not a Gentleman, a Knight, hath he not seen fashion: sir, I would have you bear a noble mind, put her away if you list, it is no matter for cause, if she change but a trencher with the Groom of your stable, it is dealing enough to be divorced, Therefore put her away, and then you may have another wife.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Another wife?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True, a gallant, and yet a modest Lady too, one that shall nourish no blood but your own , tender your reputation as the apple of her eye, and honour even your very footsteps.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: She shall go, I will make her truss up her trinkets, O faith she shall away.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Shall she away? if she do , you do you know not what, you draw a thousand thousand enemies about your ears, her kindred they will exclaim, no friends will seek revenge, and your enemies will grow even fat with laughter at your folly. Besides: what Woman then will have you, are you not gelded? assure yourself that now there is none will love you, most will hate you, but all will scorn you, therefore by my advice make much of her, and keep her while you have her.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ha! now by the virtue of my hearing, he speaks but reason.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: So, it is good to keep her still : dwell in the Suburbs to break down your own glass windows, set some picks upon your hatch, and I pray profess to keep a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Kni.
