sp.p: A Bawdy-house? No, I will die first, and if I see but any apparent show of her disloyalty, I will even be divorced immediately.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Well, I see the substance of this slave is villainy.
sp.l: But I will prevent him even what I can,
Since none is worse than a Serving honest man.

body.stage: Actus Quarti Scena prima. Enter Knight and Slacke.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Why had I not a good leg? did I not always wear clean lining? was not my hand washed, my beard combed, my cloak brushed, and my shoes blacked, every morning.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: True, why the more viler strumpet she to cuckold you.

sp.speaker: Kni,
sp.p: But how dost know she is with child.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Know it, why she is daily troubled with water pangs, and quakings over her stomach.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Indeed I must needs say that is a great proof, she hath filled her belly with something that stood against her stomach, but dost not think it is my child.

sp.speaker: Slac;
sp.p: Yours ! why how can it be yours : are you not circumcised to the quick?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Yes, and the remembrance of it galls me.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: That is a sign ye are too patient, and like an Ass endure all without resistance.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: But why do you laugh sir?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: To think who the child will be like.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why you, who should it be like else?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Why it is none of mine man.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p:
Why the more like you for that: why do you not not know the Philosophers hold the child is always like the party which the mother thinks of in the conception: now she thought most of you, for fear you should have come the whiles, and that is the reason so many Gentlemen's sons are like your Citizens, and calls them fathers too, for otherwise how could it be
that a young Cockney being left forty or fifty thousand pounds, spends all within so many months, but that some young gallant beg at him, for you know the proverb, Cat will after kind. No, had the old Citizen begotten him, he would have bit a Fig in two, to have made just weight, and have had a pot with a false bottom, rather than he sold too much measure, he would have done all things within measure as your old Citizen did, and not have spend all beyond measure, as your young Gallants do .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: But were not I best go home and use her well, till the child be born, to see if it be like me, that I may be sure it is none of mine.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O no, that were base, and as deceitful as the Colic when it breaks out in wind, which levels at a man's heel, and it strikes him in the nose, therefore never make a show of one thing, and do another , but put her away, rid your hands of her, and there is an end.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I think who is the father of the bastard?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why who is the Father of a Punks child? is it not filius populi, it may have two Fathers for anything we know.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Well Slack, I do very much mistrust Wages too, for he is grown very familiar of late.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: True sir, and takes her part too, and ye mark him

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I mark him: no Slack, no pray heaven he mark not me, but I will instantly sue out a divorce, hap, what hap shall, but ill is his hap whose wife lies down to all.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.l: Of all honest animals your Cuckold is the best,
For he is sure a Gentleman, and known by his crest.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.l: Of all occupations, that ever man professed,
In my opinion still doth hold, the Cutpurse is the best.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: And why the Cutpurse?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Because he will trust no man, foe as soon as he hath lone his work, he is sure to have his money in his hand.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Nay then a lawyer is a better trade than that, for he
is sure of his money before he doth his work.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: But I pray thee what is the news abroad now?

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: Why they say the world is like a Bias bowl, and it runs all on the rich men's sides: others say, it is like a Tennis-ball, and fortune keeps such a Racket with it, as it tosses it in to times hazard, and that devours all, and for my part they say, it will shortly run upon wheels with me, for my Master swears he will have me carted, because he thinks I have lain with my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Nay then it will run upon wheels with thee indeed, but peace fool peace, when thou art once married, that suspect will die.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Peace fool, peace, sayst thou when I am married? dost hear? I tell thee, there is no peace in marriage, unless it be with a dumb woman, no nor but little comfort neither.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: No way? why doth the Ballad say then, So sweet a thing is Love, that rules both heart and mind, there is no comfort in the world, to women that are blind.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Kind (man) the Ballet says.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Mass I think he be kind indeed, yet blind is the better of the two I think, for as thou sayst, if she be dumb, I am sure she will say nothing that shall offend her Husband: if blind, she will see nothing that shall offend her, and where he nor she is offended, there must needs be a peace: but besides this is there no peace thinkest thou in the marriage of a wife.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Yes by the man's, side like a Gentleman only by the fathers side, but it will never be any perfect peace.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why, why wilt thou marry then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Because I hope to have some good behaviour of my wife, for the peace I never look for: but soft ye fellow Slack, methinks your suit is like a hard hearted Landlord, it begins to receive great rents.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Aye , I would, my Master had given me a suite of Buff when he gave me this.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p:
Phoe, buff is naught man, that hath been out of request
ever since Soldiers have been out of date, and they poor men are now used like Almanacs of the last year, either clap up behind the door, or thrust clean out of door: but if thou wilt have a suite that shall last indeed (lad) get thee a suite of law.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: O, I do not like such suites, for commonly they that have many of them go almost naked for want of clothes, yet I cannot deny but they are very lasting, but they are subject to many discommodities: so if there be any goodness in one of them, your Lawyers like moths, eat shroud holes to it, but your Country Attorneys like lice never leave writhing and wrangling till they have crept into it, but when it hath been well worn and grown thread bare, they even like Lice drop off, and leave it.

sp.speaker: VVag:
sp.p: What sayst thou by a suite at Court then?

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: Aye marry sir, I like that well, for commonly he that hath but one suite when he comes there, hath two ere he come away, for if he sue by Petition, it lies so long in your Courtiers pocket, that it is another suit to get his Petition back again . There is none suddenly dispatched of his suite there but a Taylor, marry he stays not at all, unless his suite be to have money for his suite, and so he makes his suit two suits too ere he go. But come, shall we go see what follows after our Masters new divorce.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why is he divorced?

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: Aye , I think by this time, for he swore he would be presently. By my troth, I am sorry for it, for in my conscience it is without cause, if grieves me to see him in these humours, for I thank his Worship he hath ever used me well, I am bound to pray for his life.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: And methinks that is a strange thing, I see no reason for it that any serving-man should pray for his Masters life, considering all that he have , is in reversion of him: but come, let us follow him, for if he miss us, he will fret like a grogram I, and fume like a stew pot.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: And let him fume, O would his gall would burst with indignation, then should his temper procreate my bliss, and I enjoy that Saint incarnate: but what shall I do , since base nor noble shape can win, a third I will try.
sp.l: And if that fail knight, go to church and pray,
For vengeance wings brings on thy lethal day.

body.stage: Exeunt. Wages. Enter the olde Lord alone.

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.p: He that a long way voyage takes in hand, fears dangerous gusts at sea, and storms: At land conquering cold that cripples cursed age, and doubts lest every cloud should prove a storm, and beat his wearied carcass to the earth. But O, I would to God my longest Journey unto death were to be taken, for I do cast no doubts, having lost all comfort, My Son, I fear, is dead, The loss of him makes life to me but like a blister on my flesh, which grieves me much, and naught can ease, unless it breaks. O whilst he lived his presence was a force unto my age, and gave it such a luster as did enrich my ring of Life: for life is but a ring beginning in our weakness, going round, till unto weakness we return again, then to the ground. The world itself is but a skilful game at chesses, which being ended, Kings and Queens, Bishops and Knights into one bags are thrown at last: So all of us both poor and rich, shall in the end into the earth, as into a Bag be cast. Man's life is like unto a ship that crossed by tempests and by tides, some thoughts of his like billows swell him up a loft, another strikes him down , Thus man as on a sea is tossed, in fairest weather fears a storm, and in a storm the event, but in the end he sinks, when life is spent: grief hath no bounds in tears, it ebbs and flows. Till it have drowned life, and ended woes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But Wages, is there no means (thinkest thou) to turn by it, nor to force back his stream of wrath.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Yes I will warrant ye Madam, if you will be ruled by me, you shall see I will make him seek to be friends with you, and entreat me to speak for him too, but then I would have you seem a little strange: but you shall directly rail on him. Therefore I would have ye hide yourselves here behind the hangings, for it will not be long ere he come this way, and then you shall come forth and frame your behaviour according as our discourse shall require.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Mass here he comes, let us stand close.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: We will, and heaven assist thy projects.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now Wages, what news with you?

sp.speaker: VVag:
sp.p: That which I think will help you from being divorced.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Why your Lady is not with child.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why how should she, unless some Hobgoblin, some Incubus or spirit of the buttery should beget it? why she , since you were gelded, never saw a man but through a window: she hath never trod her foot awry, for fear some ill construction should attend her steps, which like a boundless Ocean deep enraged, would drown her reputation.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Not with child sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Not of my word sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Wages I would thou wouldst but do some charitable offices.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What? make ye friends again ?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: But you will prove false, and break that friendship?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Never , as I hope to be reconciled, therefore tell me, wilt thou do it ?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Hum: truly I would do my good will, but I fear it will be but labour lost.

sp.speaker: Kni
sp.p: I pray thee do but try: I'faith thou shalt not lose thy pains.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: O lass sir, you know I must feed on Quailes.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: That was in my fury man, but wilt thou not do it?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Pray sir, if you can get some other friend to speak in it , do.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Well, thou wilt leave me now then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Alas Sir, what would you have me do ? by my troth sir, I am ashamed to speak in it : have ye not gelded and cut off all the content of marriage? why they that have the full performance of it, it is as much as they can do to please their Wives, and you that want all ability, must not only please her now, but make her amends for the wrong you have done her heretofore, and how have I the face to promise that which I know you have no means to perform it?

sp.speaker: Kn:
sp.p: Alas man, I will do my good will.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Do your good will , and that is much worth sure, yet since you have been my master, the world shall not say but I will do what I can, I will persuade what I may, ye shall see there shall be no fault in me.
Mass here she comes: what will you do now?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: O, I will hide me here, and so I shall hear all what she says.

sp.speaker: Wag
sp.p: O this is excellent, come, come, come, and stand close, ye shall hear how I will speak for ye: and if ye hear your pardon granted, come forth.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Morrow Madam.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Morrow Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Morrow Mistress Nan.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Morrow Wages.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: The Fox is caught, his head is in the noose.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: peace, speak soft, persuade, persuade.

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: Faith Madam I have a suit unto you, but I am half a shamed to speed in it .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: 'slight, the rogue says he is a shamed to speak for me, hist Wages, hist wages.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Madam, your man would make an ill suitor, that is ashamed to speak in his suit.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: What the Devil ail you, what are you made you will be spied anon.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: A pox on thee, art not ashamed to tell her that thou art ashamed to speak for me? hist, hist, Wages.

sp.speaker: Wages:
sp.p: I think the Fool rides you, what will you have ?

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: Dost hear Wages, speak for me, and by this light I will mend thy Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: By how much?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Forty shillings.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Forty shillings?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Three pound, three pound.

sp.speaker: UUag.
sp.p: Give me your hand, I will do it

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But what is your suit Wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: That you would forgive your Husband,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What and receive his love again , you mean?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Aye Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Marry there were a jest indeed, being as he is now, a Woman would be loath to turn him amongst her ducks: truly Wages I am ashamed in your behalf, that a man of your discretion would urge it, therefore prithee speak no more on it, I will tell thee what, I could find in my heart to speak for him myself , but that it is such a jealous fool, that if he catch but a Flea in her bed, he will be searching to see if it be a male or a female, for fear he
comes to Cuckold him.

sp.speaker: Lad:
sp.p: Well Wages well: to tell thee truly, I bear no malice, and if I wist he would amend, I should forgive and love him

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Ye faith I will wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why how now Wages, have you betrayed us ?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Aye , Madam, but it is into the hands of those that love ye .

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Well Wages well, I did not think you would have used us thus.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Is there honesty in this, to set a man behind the hangings to eavesdrop our words.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Be not angry sweet wife, i'faith it was my plot, but you have been a heavy enemy of mine.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It was more for my credit than to have been your light friend.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Be friends with me good wife, for here I do confess.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Your Jealousy sprung from your own unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: It is true.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Then in hope you will kinder prove, I am content,
For this know, a Woman's heart will soon relent.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: Then, come sweet wife, let us in,
sp.l: And Wages, thy pains deserves to be requited,
For separated hearts, hast thou united.

body.stage:
Exeunt omnes.
Enter Nuecome singing with a Glasse in his hand, and making himselfe ready.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: La, la, la, la, la, they marched out manly by three, and by three, and the foremost in Battle, was Mary Hanbrie. Will you hear of a Spanish Lady, how she wooed an Englishman: hum, hum, hum. Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Is the Taylor gone?

sp.speaker: Bo:
sp.p: Gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Go fetch me my doublet then,

sp.speaker: Bo:
sp.p: I go sir.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, by the greatest terror to Gentility, which indeed is Creditors and Sergeants, this roguey Taylor came upon me with such a bill as a man were better have ten Constables and their Watches come upon him with their bills: why good words, or a dozen of ale will please them, but nothing will stop this rogues mouths but money: and yet i'faith I am greatly in his books, for though I misuse him never so much, yet the Rogue durst not cross me.
Let me see Boy, mass it is a pretty Doublet.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Taylor sir, entreats you to remember your day.

sp.speaker: Nuc:
sp.p: My day? Gods light, my day? why what doth he take me for, I think?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He takes you for a Gentleman sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: A Gentleman, and remember my day, no, I will hold my life he takes me for some Merchant or Citizen, but I will make him know my strength, ere I leave him, he shall find a second Sampson of me . I can break my bonds boy, I can, I can.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: But come sir, will you try your doublet first.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: O Aye , come, come pluck, but take heed of my ruff I pray thee: this doublet is too little, a pox in him.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Not now, he is on sir.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Now when he is off, I mean boy.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Believe it sir, but it becomes ye well though.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Doth it indeed? mass I think it do, methinks I have a reasonable good leg in it .

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: So you have sir, but your heel is a little too short.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Yea, why too short?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Because your long heel sir doth always best become your great Calf.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Why? my Calf is not very great.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: O sir yes, why a man shall not see a greater Calf of your age, For I think you are not above twenty.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Not so much, but come help off my doublet now.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Come, I will see how it will look here , and go thou and watch the door, that nobody come the whilst, hum, hum, hum, if I had a band for it .

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Why that about your neck sir.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: But what if anybody should come the whilst?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Why do not I keep the door?

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Mass that is true: hum, hum, hum. O it is Master Nuecome, I know him, a fine Gentleman i'faith I will salute him by and by as I pass. Master Nuecome I take it, I cry ye heartily mercy good Master Nuecome, I am glad to see you in good health sir, I shall entreat you to pardon me , I protest I did not know you in that suite, you have a very fair doubleton, the Gods give you joy sir: There is never a Lord in the Land may be ashamed to wear it sir,
Gods light carry away my Doublet quickly, quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I warrant ye sir.

body.stage: Enter a Messenger. Enter a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: Gods precious my Band, what shall I do now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: By your leave sir, my mistress, mistress Peg sent to see how your worship doth.

sp.speaker: Nue:
sp.p: I thank her very heartily, I pray commend me to her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will do your commendations sir, but I pray you be covered sir, I pray yon be covered.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: I thank ye heartily, it is for mine ease, the weather is hot, hot, very hot.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: So it is indeed sir, well sir, by your leave sir, I will be so bold sir as to carry your commendations sir.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Do so good friend, farewell, farewell.

What a beast was I to put off my band, yet the griefs the less, because he came from Peg, which is a Wench I must confess dotes on my exterior virtues, but I can by no means affect her: only , because the poor Wretch, in heat of her passion shall not melt herself away in tears, she sometimes enforceth me to swear and protest I affect her, marry always with mental reservations for my souls health, for you know that sometimes it is policy Courtiers and Statesmen should use fallacy.

body.stage: Exit Nuecome. Enter the Lady with a seruant.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Give charge unto the cook a make not too much haste with supper, for I hope your master will be here tonight , and look you keep fast the door, let no man trouble me.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Now thanks gentle heavens, O be you smiling still on my designs, and let your influence pour down good fortunes, and be not angry, nor no more malevolent, but make my husbands reconcilement irrevocable.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be shent for letting of you in.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: 'Sblood I tell thee I will speak with her, what wouldst thou bar my chance when my whole fortunes lies on the cast.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O heavens, stars, fates, Gods smile not like Summer on these Wasps no longer, that daily buzzing come to sting my honour.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.p: Save thee sweet Lady, I hear thy husband is from home, which makes me come to tender thee my persons love.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Your parsons Love (sir) is most commonly a benefice, O that I should be troubled with this Ass now, do you hear sir, if my husband should come and find you here we were both undone.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Your husband, your husband is an ass, by this light and he should offer you but an ill look in my sight, it were better he had no eyes: but it is your own fault that would not ere now accept of the love of a Soldier, to have kept the slave in some awe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O! how reproachfully the Captain swaggers, I will away, for fear he grow furious.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But dost hear me sweet Lady, I have loved thee long, and must now enjoy thee. Fear nothing: this warlike sword of mine shall defend thine honour, this Martial blade shall do it : life it shall i'faith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Hark, hark, my husband is come.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: Your Husband, ha! where, where?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It is not he? but I will try my Captains valour now . O sir, my husband, what shall I do now, he hath a Pistol in his hand too, he will kill us both.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A pistol? cods my life, what shall I do then? I pray hide me some where.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O no! as ye love me, must enjoy me , and will defend my honour, draw forth this warlike sword: this is the martial blade must do it, therefore I beseech you good Captain now or never .

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: Gods precious woman, he hath a pistol, a sword no shield against a bullet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O no, no, it is but a sword, now I think on it .

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: That is all one, for Jove's sake hide me, if you can.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why? durst you not encounter with him sword to sword?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Durst! yes I durst, and beat him too, but for your reputation, your honour, it will call your name in question.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O it is no matter for that, hark, hark, defend me but from his fury now, and I care not for that.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Death of man, what should I do now? why look ye Lady, in your defence I would beat him like a Dog, but he will have the law on me, he will undo me with actions

body.stage: She lookes at the dore againe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Believe me Captain I have been mistaken all this while, it is but a poniard that he hath in his hand.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: Soul of valour Woman, the most dangerous thing in the world, he may either throw it, or stab suddenly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Faith Captain I know not where I should hide you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why anywhere sweet Lady, if it be under your farthingale.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No, no, come stand here .

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.p: Where, where, quickly, pray quickly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Stand close, take heed, do not move till I call you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well Captain, I hope I have coled your courage for coming here again , and now I will see who is at the door.

body.stage: She opens the doore, and enters Maister Exhibition.

sp.speaker: Exh.
sp.p: Your fair lips fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady:
sp.p: Yet more flesh flies, what shall I do with them. Well I fear fortune hath dealt me a bad game by the shuffling of her Cards thus, That these two Knaves should come together.

sp.speaker: Exh:
sp.p: You have a pretty sweet dwelling here Lady, I will even presume here to uncase myself .

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: Then I am sure we shall have music, for they say, every fool is a Fiddle to the company.

body.stage: He Capers three or foure times.

sp.speaker: Kni
sp.p: What, have you never a pair of Virginals in the house Lady?

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: Indeed that were good music for the Merchants Daughter, but it is not good for students of the Inns a court.

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p: Have you ever a lute then.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Neither indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p: Faith Lady I remember the first time I saw you, was in Quadragessimo sexto of the Queen, in a Michaelmas Term, and, as I think it was the morrow upon the Mense Michaelis, or Crastino animarum, I cannot well tell which but it was at the Christening of Justice warrants child, and the second time I saw you was at our Revels, where it pleased your Ladyship, to grace me with a galliard, and I shall never forget it, for my velvet pantofles were stolen away the whilst.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I was beholding to you for so costly a Galliard.

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p: In troth not a whit Lady, for I must confess unto you I have been since primo of the King. It may be you fear to entertain my love, because there are a number of idle fellows of our society, I must needs confess: which are very scandalous to the reputation of Ladies: but those are but your punies lately come from the University, such as take so much on them by the reading of Aristotles problems, as they think they could teach their own Fathers to make Children: but I am none of those, I love you, and if you doubt it, be you but to the charge to sue out a Dedimus potestatime, and I will presently make ye affidavit of my affection.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray Jove he do not conjure in welsh, for I know not what he says.

sp.speaker: Exhi.
sp.p:
Or make me a lease but for term of life of your lone in the remainder of your Husband, provided always, if your Husband alien (or put away) it may be lawful for me to enter, but if I alien (or put away your affection) let it be then lawful for your foresaid husband, again to
receive, and then to have , hold, manure and occupy in statu quo prius, that is in the state before: and I do not doubt but your grant in this case will be good, for there is a case that proves this in quinto of Rich the third: a patro was seized of an aduowsio in fee, with two nuns appedat, and thereunto presented a parso, with a proviso, that if the incumbent should alien grat, demise, let, set, or otherwise put away the premises, or any part or parcel thereof, that then it should be lawful for the patron (or his assigns) in and upon the whole to re-enter. The incumbent aliened, the Patron entered, the Quare was, whether those two Nuns were any part of the premises, and by virtue of the proviso subject to the reentries and after long dispute it was agreed by all the Court, that the entry was good, as well in the two Nus, as in the rest of the premises. The much more in this case, where we are both lay me.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: Sure this fellow thinks he hath some right to me, and he hopes to win me by law, but what think ye : if my husband should come and enter now upon us two, in what case were you?

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p: Why well enough, perchance he would complain of me to the bench, and then I should be put out of commons: that is the worst he could do , and that is nothing: for I was once put out of commons before, for beating of the panyard man: and in again within three days after.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: O Madam, madam, what will you do ? my master is come as I am a living man.

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: O lass sir, what shall I do with you?

sp.speaker: Exh.
sp.p: Why hide me somewhere , cannot ye hide me here ?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O no, no, no, he doth use to search all the house still, to see if he can find anybody here , but I will tell ye what ye shall do , draw out your rapier and go out against him, and whatsoever question he ask you, make him no answer, but only say, ye doubt not for all this, but you shall meet him and be revenged dwell enough in another place, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Exh:
sp.p: I warrant ye.

body.stage: Exeunt Exhibition and Seruant Enter Knight.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Come out, come out man.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: 'slight woman your husband will see me.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: 'sprecious man, that is all one, come out, come out, draw your sword, hold it in your hand, make some show of resistance.

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.p: 'Sblood woman he hath a pistol.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: He hath none, he hath none, by this hand I did but jest.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nor no other weapon?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nor no other weapon?

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: i'faith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why will ye not believe me! i'faith he hath not.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.p: Well then, well, nay I care not if he had.

sp.speaker: Kni
sp.p: Why how now Wife, what is the matter? what stir have we here ?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why husband did you not meet a man with a rapier drawn in his hand?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Yes, and here is another.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Alas husband, he would have killed this poor Gentleman, but that he came and ran in here for shelter, and because I would not suffer him spoil him here in your house, he is gone in such a rage as you never saw.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: My faith, and he swore indeed he would be revenged in another place: did he not Wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: he did indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Believe me, and he might easily have slain you sir, for he had a very long rapier.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: True, I know myself he had the better weapon, or else I would never have stood so against him.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Aye , had I such a rapier, I would have made him run like an Irish Lackey.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: Aye , to have overtaken ye.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: Well wife, believe me, I thank ye for this: for I would not for the wealth of all this town he should have hurt him in my house, well sir you shall sup with me : and after supper I will conduct you to your lodging myself , but fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

body.stage: Actus Quinti Scaena prima. Enter Knight and Slacke.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why did you not perceive it?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Not, I protest.

sp.speaker: Sla
sp.p: O monstrous! why did she not say herself , she knew he had the better weapon, for which cause she stood against him, meaning Bawdry, flat bawdry, and yet you could not perceive it: now by this light, had you stepped but one foot lighter, ye had taken them in the very fact, but you go dreaming hanging down your head, that it is no marvel your wife makes you a Cuckold: for the husband being the wives head, why when the head goes down thus, the heels must needs mount up .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I will never more hear of reconcilement, but be divorced immediately.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Straight put her away, why you may have wives enough.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: O wives too much.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: There is your wives Kinswoman Mistress Peg, she is fair, modest, honest, chaste, wise, sober, rich, virtuous discreet and honourable.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And would he be acquainted with me sayst?

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: The man thou speakest of.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Why I speak of none, I talk of a woman,

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: And have all these good conditions.

sp.speaker: Slac:
sp.p: Aye , why not?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Dost know her.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: Aye .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Hark then, rent a chamber, hang out her picture, take twelve pence a piece at the least,
sp.l: For enough will come I know:
To see that which none else can show.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.p: 'slight I think the man be mad, but will ye not have her sir?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p:
Yes, if thou tell true, who would not have her: but
first make winged speed to purchase my divorce, hold
sp.l: here is money, make haste , use no delay,
For all men must for expedition pay.

sp.speaker: Sla.
sp.p: I go, and you shall be divorced or else my brain shall sweat: for what your folly loseth, my wit shall get.

body.stage: Exit Slacke at one doore, and enter Wages at the other.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: O Wages, I will tell thee news, I have sent for a divorce, and what wilt thou say when I am married to a new wife?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Then sir will I say as the proverb says, marriage and hanging comes by destiny: but if ye be divorced, and will follow my counsel you shall hang yourself , rather than marry again .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: No Wages, I do not hold that so good: for sure, marriage is better than hanging in some.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: True, in some respect, and that only because you have a longer time of repentance, but I pray sir, is it a christian that you mean to marry?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: A Christian! Aye , why dost think I would marry a jew?

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: I do not like that so well sir, because it is the fashion amongst them to send Capons to their Godfathers for New years gifts, and upon my life sir, she will one time or other clap you up in a basket, and send you away for good handsel: but I pray sir who is it?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Peg, is she not a fine Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Beyond praise.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Hath she not a piercing eye?

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: If it were a Ferret.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: A delicate nose.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: If it were a Mulberry.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Teeth like two rows of orient pearl.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: But the string is broken and many of them are fallen out.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Hands as white as Pelops shoulder.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Aye , and as thick too.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Wages.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Go to her, and measure by thy protestations the depth of my affections: tell her what I will be to her, not what I have been to others: if she allege to thee her cousins presupposed wrongs, tell her , I well could have been hoodwinked to her cousins faults, so I had never seen her face.

sp.speaker: VVag.
sp.p: But what shall I tell her if she say you are gelded?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Aye there is it indeed, there is no excuse for that: yet thou mayst tell her, I did it only to preserve my voice. Deliver this Jewel to her hand, and with it even my hearts affection.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I will sir, and if the Wenches close my projects carry, spite of mischance you shall your own wife marry.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now must I be frolic, learn to speak well, and woo with a good garb: and now I think of it , I have a pretty conceit of mine own , I will tell her that the wooing of a young wench, is the felling of a tree, and the getting of her friends good will , like the lopping of the tree, therefore first it behooves me to hew down the tree and then I will climb with ease: but if at first to fell it I be not able, to assay to climb it shall be in vain. Welcome, hast thou brought the divorce.

sp.speaker: Sla:
sp.p: It is here sir.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Come then, let us in, it joys me much that thou so soon hast sped, For hours seem years, till it be published.

body.stage: Exeunt Omnes. Enter Lady, Nan, and Peg.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But tell me good Madam, why are you so melancholy?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: To think upon the saucy importunity of my Servant Slack: he is like a badge on a coat, he is never off, off my sleeve, and yet I shun him like the pest.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: And he follows you like infection.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay I would he did so by me, for I protest I love him beyond my thoughts, I covert nothing like his company, and yet he hates me, loathes my sight, but then comes the welshman your love, and he hangs on my lips like a Padlock on a Peddlers Budget.

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: And hates me as much, for if I come but near him, he swears I am like a Kybe, always at his heels.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Come Madam, do not grieve at that which grief can no way mend.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: I would not, if I could mend that which doth cause my grief.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: News, news.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What news.

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: You are divorced.

sp.speaker: La,
sp.p: Why divorced, why? ha, speak.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot speak the cause Madam? but questionless it is true, and mistress Peg, my master now makes love to you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: To me?

sp.speaker: Na:
sp.p: To thee, Aye to thee, go thy ways, thou shalt be a Lady, I ever thought thou wouldst come to some promotion, at the boy did that had a bag and a staff and begged for himself , but how dost thou know he is in love with her.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Know it why I have seen him stand an hour together behind an Oaken tree, calling it sweet mistress, kind Peg and making speeches to it.

sp.speaker: Na,
sp.p: As how? as how? prithee how?

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: Stand you for the tree, and I will speak for my Master.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I will, and that most stiffly i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.p: Then thus he begins: Dear mistress Peg I must confess.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Nay then he is a dead man already.

sp.speaker: Wa
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Why confess and be hanged ever .

sp.speaker: Wa:
sp.p: O ho, but I mean he doth confess she is fair.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That is all one, he is but one man, and one witness can never prove her fact, but prithee on with thy speech.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why then this fair Mistress I must confess.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: But he will not confess before witness will he?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Push, did not I tell you he would speak to an Oak.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Nay, then that will be a strong proof indeed.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Proof, Nay, if that be not proof, how say by this token.

sp.speaker: Na,
sp.p: Aye marry sir, would we had more such tokens of his love.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: This Mistress he hath sent to you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Look you Madam, your husband now makes love to me.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Sir how pert thou art, why look woman, your love as mad woes me , and to me sent this ring.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And my man the man you so esteem, spite of refusal left with me this chain.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: This chain: for ever may he linked be to woe, that hates my love, and woes another so.

sp.speaker: VVag:
sp.p: Well, let us in, and be but patient all awhile, for if the worst do fall, that ever did fall, A plot is in chase that shall out strip them all

body.stage: xeunt. Omnes. Enter Knight and Cupid before him.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Now if she should refuse my Jewel and contemn my love, or contemn my love, and take my Jewel: what a fool was I to send her a token till I had some token of her affection, as if women might be wooed with gifts, for when we give them those things which most we love, they do esteem we love them better than those things we give, when they poor fools do but deceive themselves , for we do give as Merchants venture, for a treble: again we send them tokens only to get them and their portions. But there comes my persecutor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Why dost thou haunt me like a Ghost, thou female sinner: thou hast not holy church in thy power with all her
commandments, to keep me from thy unhallowed presence: how durst thou break the Edict pronounced by the mouth of holy Church Man? art thou not Divorced? is not our separation blown into the peoples ears, even by Iehouahs chosen Trumpeter? First, thou didst break thy vow to me , and madest of every Priapus a Trumpet; on which thou blowedest thine own infamy: therefore avoid, thou leavened lump of sinfulness, avoid.
O my still beloved Husband, like filth or dirt, do not flea me like a Serpent, which comes to sting thy bosom; I come to kiss; Sweet let not suspect divorce me from thy presence, though from thy bed:
sp.l: For if you will trust this masked face, I know.
No fountain purer than my Love would show.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: I fly, and hate thee like a Serpents hissing,
which comes to sting me with pretence of kissing.

sp.p: O fainty tears, and feeble hands, for ever may you close, and never part till sharpest grief have cut the heartstrings of my life. Or else let this same brain of mine dissolve to tears, and drop itself even drop by drop, until it make a Sea of woes, that therein I may drown my wretched life.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: Alas poor Lady, I pity your calamity, and grieve to see you bruised by my Masters injury, which makes your eyes like sponges drop these brinish tears, and spoils a Face, such as was never better one framed by the skilful hand of Nature.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Avoid thou slave, how durst thou woe me ? I am like a star to thee; my Orb is above thee.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: O! then my Love is a most clear and brightest star: look not with a malevolent Aspect upon me, but let your eyes bright raise up my life, and so extol my thoughts

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Perish may thyself and love together: Heavens grant again , I never may hear of either .

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: What shall I do ?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Respect her most, that most of all loves you. O! do not turn away those Eyes, whose radiant beams first nursed my flame.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: Avoid thou unresistable Torturer, more fretting to my thoughts than Cankers are to Metals. How often have I told thee of my hatred? For of this be thou sure and still remembered: deep hate (like love) can hardly be dissembled.

sp.speaker: Nan.
Nuc.
sp.p: O here she is; pray God my Band sit well. Fair Lady, may I presume with the Bee to suck Honey from thy lips, for I dreamed thee last night.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nay, I thought he would woo me dreaming like a Welshman.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: That I was transfigured, metamorphosed, or transformed into a flea in thy Bed.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: But did I not kill ye then?

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: Methought you did did, but first I dreamed I stung you.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Yet again dreaming, I will talk no more, but be gone; for fear I wake him.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: And then methought , as I was skipping from your knee unto your thigh, and so forth; you told a Gentleman of it, a friend of yours; who most courtly and softly putting in his hand to catch me . 'sprecious she is gone, sure it is the acuteness of my ingenuity, which makes my jests so stinging, as she cannot endure them: I must needs eat some of your new court-water-gruel, to qualify my my invention:

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Thou needst not love, speak what thou wilt, if gently thou do speak, thy words to me are much more Musical than is a Sirens voice. Orpheus himself could never strain his high stretched strings to such Melodious sounds, as when thy voice doth pierce the ear.

sp.speaker: Nuc.
sp.p: It is but for my wit she loves me: I sent her tricks already:
sp.l: for Courtiers must as well thriving be ,
Have Noses to smell out, as Eyes to see.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Despised, and left alone, filled brim full of grief, and no way to unload me of my cares. But through these running eyes, in streams of tears.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Whose tears like to a clear, yet poisoned source, have with their vapours through these eyes (the windows to my heart) infected all my thoughts. Thy eyes do shoot forth glances like to stars, though seated in a moist and rainy Sky, the which hath wounded even my heart, and I must die; Lest Achilles lance-like, healed by your eye.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: I pray you seek some-where else, if you be ill,
For I in Surgery have little skill.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: I will follow my suit, not ceasing till the most of trial,
For he is a fool in Love that makes denial.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: Here hath been a Maze, a Round, a Whirling in Love,
How like the spokes of a Ladies Coach-wheels
They run one after another:
And as of them you see neither ,
So none of these can overtake either .
And though you see them thus forsaken,
They shall be married, but mistaken:
Which for performance yet a while,
I must be labouring to beguile.
Only the men, and make them venture,
To run a Circle far from Centre
Of their hopes; yet for their good,
Where blinded each like Hawk in hood,
Shall Marry better than they Wooed.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Nay Madam, it must needs be so, or else the Priest will never Marry me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And so you would have us all be Married masked.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: True, to which you all may easily persuade your Lovers, telling them with my Marriage, will be with much the less suspect effected.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: But say, who shall know us , when our Faces are not seen?

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: The better; for then you shall appoint each one of them, To choose you by their own Tokens, which you within ourselves shall change: Mistress Peg shall wear Mistress Nans Ring, Mistress Nan your Chain, and you Mistress Pegs jewel.

sp.speaker: Lad:
sp.p: But shall they need to come naked too?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O Aye , by any means, only for some private reasons unto me , in which persuasion if you will practise that you know, you will prevail.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will do my best most willingly.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Then come Madam, let us in: I know it will do :
sp.l: For this is held a principle in Schools,
Love makes not fools wise men, but wise men fools.

sp.p: Nominatiuo, hic, haec, hoc.
A Noun is the name of a thing.
In speech be these eight parts.

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor.
sp.p: I promise you sir, I had Dined forth today , but that you see the weather is Cloudy, and the Heavens lower on my delights.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: I pray you sir, whose Son is that bigger Boy?

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p:
It is Master Parmisins son the Cheese-monger, and the next to him is Master Cauctas son the Ferryman,
two very pretty sparks I will assure you. Tobias Parmasin, come hither Tobias, hold up your head Tobias, and look if you can see a penny in my brow: So, it is well done; What part of speech is Mentula?
A noun Adjective.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: And why a noun adjective?
Because it stands not by himself , but it requires another word to be joined with it.

sp.speaker: M. C.

sp.p: Jam, jam , O Iohn, Iohn, putes , do thou put, Sidera, summa, Cider in Summer, Tacturus, in Tankards.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: A very forward child, I promise ye.

sp.speaker: Maist. C.
sp.p: Go sit you down again : Will you hear them all examined Sir?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Moss willingly good good Master Correction.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Ye shall sir; Sir, I have taken as much pains with them, as any Poet whatsoever could have done, to make them answer upon their Q. with good action, distinction, and deliberation: ha, ha, ha, how many devils are there?
Number infinite.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Look you Sir, there are an infinite number of Devils: What is the Devil?
A wicked Spirit.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: What is the nature of that wicked spirit?
To work mischief.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: On whom doth it work mischief?
On all mankind.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: When hath he most power to work mischief?
When Man hath taken his liquor.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: With what visitations then deludes he mankind?
With strange Earthquakes.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: What is the man's best comfort?
To sleep and slumber.

sp.speaker: M. Cor.
sp.p: Look ye now sir, are they not pretty children?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Very pretty, and well taught, I will assure you sir.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Sir, I will tell you, notwithstanding all these pains I take with them, yet how unkindly their Parents use me: they suffer their younger Children to bewray the Church porch: And no longer since then Monday last, came the Official, and there being angry with me about other matters, he threw that in my dish, as if I could have helped it: but I answered him sufficiently: For I told him, they that did it, were but the Children and the youth, and youth would break out in despite of his Nose; or the best man's Nose in the parish.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: I think ye spend most of your time with your Scholars here: ye keep little other company.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Yes sometimes sir, here was yesterday Master Nucome the Courtier, do you not know him sir?

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: O very well sir.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: He is a fine Gentleman, a good Scholar, and an excellent Naturalist: and truly fell into a great disputation, (peace these Boys there) and our Argument was, whether a Fool or a wise man made the best Lawyer. He stood for the Wise man, and I most Scholastically, stood for the Fool: and thus I began my Syllogism, (peace these Boys when I bid ye) your wise man (said I) useth few words, your Fool, much babbling; your best Lawyers use much babbling. Ergo, your Fools makes the best Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: And believe me sir, it was well proved.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: A flash, a flash, a foolish School-point, a foolish school-point.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: O Aye , and confuted me too, only by reason of a scurvy old Proverb which says, Children and Fools do always tell true: but your best Lawyers do not always tell true: Ergo, your Fools make not your best Lawyers, a most strong and strange Argument.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I pray Master Correction, let me entreat a Play day for your Scholars.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: O Master Wages, they do nothing else, they do nothing but play, nothing but play.

sp.speaker: Wag:
sp.p: Nay good sir, do not deny me, for I have some private business with you of great importance.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Nay then sir you shall prevail indeed: you shall, yet I remember; Dyonisius ille Tyranus, Scycilie crudelissimus, crudelissimus Scicilie Tyrannus ille Dyonisius: says to one of his Pupils: Huc ades, haec animo, concipe dictatus. So I say unto you all my Masters, reuerere Mayoress: pluck off your Hats to your betters, and look ye give the Woman the wall, and so go your ways.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Gratias: Gratias: Gratias: Gratias:

body.stage: Exeunt omnes Schollars. Enter Mistris Correction.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Morrow Mistress Correction.

sp.speaker: Mistris Cor.
sp.p: Morrow good Wages.

sp.speaker: Maister Corr.
sp.p: Morrow sweet Wife, sweet Frisset, sweet Nuptial.

sp.speaker: Mistris Corr.
sp.p: O Master Wages! how doth your good Master, sir Timothie Troublesome? what, doth he think he is a Cuckold still?

sp.speaker: Maist. Corr.
sp.p: An arrant Cuckold (Wife) believe it.

sp.speaker: Mistris Corr.
sp.p: Come, come, Husband, you are such another; why do you say so?

sp.speaker: Ma. Corr:
sp.p: Because it is true, Wife.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Sir, Master Correction you are mistaken, I think he be no Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor:
sp.p: Good Master Wages talk no more of Cuckolds; I would they were all in the Sea for my part.

sp.speaker: Mi. C.
sp.p: Husband, can you swim?

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: No Wife, nor I desire not to learn.

sp.speaker: Mi. C.
sp.p: I would have you in any case appoint with my Husband that I may come masked.

sp.speaker: Wages.
sp.p: Peace, that plot is already drawn, Master Correction, I am sent unto you from my master, who commends his Love unto you, entreating you will give your diligent attendance this Evening at the Church, because himself upon his Divorce, is privately to be married to a new wife: three other couples he brings with him, they all come masked, yet I will give you private notice what each one is: only I must desire you not to sail.

sp.speaker: Maist. Cor.
sp.p: Master Wages, your Master is the helm by which my labours are governed: and tell him I will steer all the navy of my actions by his directions: And so I pray commend me back to him. Well sir then, till then Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mai. Cor.
sp.p: The like to you sir. Come Wife, I hope that thou shalt thrive, for as all your Cockatrices maintain surgeons by their issues: So doth the Priest and Midwife agree: I set them together, they make work for thee.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: And truly Husband, I will come to their labours, be it at midnight, if they send for me.

body.stage: Exeunt omnes. Enter Ladie, Nan, and Peg.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Doth my Tire sit well Nan?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Passing well, I will assure you Madam.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: prithee tell me too, how am I dressed?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why thou art very well dressed too, but basted admirably: for the threads sit in thy Gown, Marry thou wantest a little Cramming.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And that is pity; for I can tell you, I am of myself a rare bit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nay then thou art for the Serving-men, for your Gallants (I can assure you) ride altogether with a snaffle.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Come, thou hast such a deal of wit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Indeed I had, before I spent it amongst such unthankful persons as you are Peg; but I prithee pin, my Gown close before: for it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: That I will, but why then dost thou obscure thy Bravery? this thy Petticoat is a great deal richer than thy Gown.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Faith Aye , I wear my clothes as your Gallants wear their wits, the best side inwards, I scorn to show it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But for all this Idle talk, I would we had appointed our marriage tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Then the people would a stood gazing on us , and besides, we should have been like thee in dutch, subject to every Cobblers interpretation, but now being married in the evening, presently bed time follows.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Phoe, but it is not the fashion.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Tut, hang fashion, I love it in nothing but my clothes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why, thou knowest it is not the fashion in all places to lie with ones own husband every night. 'slight I had rather lie with a man, and never marry him, then marry a man and never lie with him, come, come, I speak my mind freely, I am none of these simpering wenches that come at every , word and says Aye forsooth, and no forsooth, and blushes at the sight of a child, it puts her in mind how it was made and cries faugh at a wanton jest in a play, and hearkens to a bawdy tale in her ear.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Aye, it is but dishonourable to marry thus in huggermugger, men will say we are with child, and are ashamed to show our faces.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Our faces! why our faces I hope do not show us to be with child, it is our bellies shows that, and I hope thou art quick flesh and not dead fish, thou wilt not turn up the white of thy belly, woo it? but prithee tell me, was I not married yesterday?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yesterday, why dost ask?

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: Because, like a young married woman that is poisoned before she is bawd, I begin to long already.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: For what I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Faith to be a bed with my husband.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Aye , alas woman, those that are past child bearing, use to long for that too.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Nay, but my longing yet methinks stretches a great deal longer, for I long to be a Widow, that I might have a new Husband: yet not for any concupiscent desires, that I have in the world.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, I think so too, but only a desire thou hast to try the difference of men, and therefore I think thou wert best next to marry an old man with a white head, because thou mayst sleep quiet and not be troubled a nights.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By this light I had as live marry a Saint Dauis Leek, no, no, take this of me, where ever thou seest the Snow lie on the Mountains, be assured there is no great heat in the valley.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Let me see, I would be a

sp.speaker: Peg:
sp.p: A Priests wife I warrant ye, because thou wouldst fare costly, and live lazily.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: No Nan, then marry a Londoner, for then thou shalt live a life and it were a Lady, wear thy gold necklace, and go in thy Velvet cap every day.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: True, and then when thy husband is a broad in traffic for commodities, in other countries, why thou mayst deal at home for ready money

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: No not a Londoner by no means.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, why?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Why if they have but a plague amongst them one weak they all cry out of a dead time straight, besides, if they receive but a little loss at sea, they break straight, and where the husband breaks, you know the wife can no longer hold out, she must down too for want of maintenance.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Nay then marry a Soldier, for questionless most of them will use their wives well , for they love their punks exceedingly.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: O but they have a vile fault too, for they always beget their children by day, and then they be squint eyed, for when the Father looks one way, and the mother another, to see if anybody come the whilst, how can the child look right?

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: What sayst thou by a Civilian Nan.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
O no, by no means, foremost of their posterity have ill luck, for what their fathers get by bawdy courts, they commonly spend it all again in bawdy houses, No and ever I marry again, I will marry an Irish Merchant, because they all speak latin, and indeed are most of them Philosophers by fortune: Omnia mea mecum porto for they carry all their ware in their breech: but come, let us make haste
away, I fear our lovers do our coming stay.

body.stage: Exeunt Om. Enter the old Lord, and the Marchant.

sp.speaker: Old Lord:
sp.p: You see master Venture, the greatest comfort that is left me now, is only in my neighbours loves, where are these knaves there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: What have they supped within.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Not yet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: Why so, thou art an honest knave, go see that none want wine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: I would not have the worst complain of scarcity or want of anything , for Master Venture we shall carry nothing with us , for naked we into the world came, without that which we now possess and have , and without it we must unto the grave.

O Sir Iohn, Sir Iohn, I thank you for your homely today , but it you have a fault sir Iohn, the which in any of your Scholars would deserve a whipping: you are come too late, Aye and to a feast and all, well, well, well, but you shall fare the worse for this sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ma. Co:
sp.p: I would desire a word in private with your honour.

sp.speaker: Old. Lor:
sp.p: With all my heart:
They shall be welcome, even exceeding welcome, and I thank you too.

Hark you neighbour, Sir Iohn tells me that to honour me in this my predecessors still accustomed feast, four new married couples are hither come in a mask, newly from the church, their feet not yet since their nuptial, have kissed their own thresholds.

body.stage: Enter Maiste correciion, Cupid and the maskers dauncing

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: It is Sign ye are well beloved my Lord.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p:
I am indeed the Master Venture, I am indeed.
Gentlemen and Women, ye are all welcome even with my heart, I with my heart i'faith. O neighbour Venture my Son and your Daughter now be married, what a joyful mask would this have been .

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: It is true my Lord, but they are fled beyond all hope of ever seeing them again ,

sp.speaker: Old Lo.
sp.p: It is true, it is true, yet though the fruit gone be, my grief you see, like leaves stick fast upon this tree. but come neighbour come, let us sit and look upon this youthful dancing mirth, for youth and mirth have danced themselves out at heels with me. Nay, pray Gentlemen unmask, that we may know to whom we shall be thankful for this honour, how now my Son?

body.stage: The first couple vnmaske and kneele.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.p: My Daughter.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: Now may my blessing raise thee from the ground.

sp.speaker: Uen:
sp.p: And mine make thee both fruitful, and a faithful wife.

sp.speaker: Slacke.
sp.p: Why what are you?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Mistook of you, but such is woman's fantasy,
Constant in nothing but unconstancy:
For I that first you most abhorred,
Loved you a slave, and hated you a Lord.

sp.speaker: Slac.
sp.l: Well, woodcock like by thy bill, it is my hap,
Thus fast to be catched in a woman's trap.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Now by my conscience I am deceived.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: No, not a whit, for I will love you ever .

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.l: Well, give me your hand then, since it is my fate,
What marriage joins, I will never separate.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What now, remarried?

body.stage: Sir Timothy and his wife vnmasked

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: O! I repent it not, this match is double made, and twice hath holy Hymens fingers tide the knot.

sp.speaker: Nue.
sp.p: Well, since it is thus, hence forth I will love thee ever , for que sera, sera, against what plots so ever , but who is this, master Correction?

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: A friend of yours.
'sprecious it is my wife.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: O then sir it is a friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Ma. C.
sp.p: Come ye away housewife, come ye from him, come.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Faith sir no, why is he not my husband? did not you yourself marry me to him? but do you hear, you were best be quiet and let me alone, if not, i'faith I will tell all.

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor.
sp.p: Tell what thou canst, justice, my Lord Justice, I beseech ye for Justice.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech your Lordship too, though I am but a weak vessel called a Woman, and therefore by reason of my bashfulness unable sir to set forth mine own tale, yet I doubt not, but I shall find good hearing at your Lord ships had, if ye will but give me leave to ope mine own case.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: Speak, what are your grievances.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: May it please your honour in few words, my husband hath four wives, and then I hope it is as lawful for me to have two husbands.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: How do you answer this Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ma. Cor.
sp.p: If it like your honour, I think it is a lawful for me to have four wives, as it is for my parson to have four benefices, considering I use them as he doth his benefices, for I protest to your honour, I never came near none of them.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Will not this do it Master Wages?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: No, you see, he hath answered it.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Nay then if it like your Lordship, I may be divorced for another thing, but that I am ashamed to speak of it .

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Nay, you must tell what it is .

sp.speaker: M. Cor.
sp.p: Truly I am half ashamed.

sp.speaker: Old Lor.
sp.p: Come, come woman, never be ashamed to tell true.

sp.speaker: Mi: Cor.
sp.p: And I may be so bold to tell your honour in private.

sp.speaker: Old Lo.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mi. Co.
sp.p: Truly and like your honour, he hath not that a man should have .

sp.speaker: Old. Lo.
sp.p: No, why what doth he want.

sp.speaker: M. C.
sp.p: Nay pray your Lordship to spare me now, faith I am ashamed.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: Nay good Mistress Correction, I must know what it is.

sp.speaker: Mi. Cor.
sp.p: Why then sir I must needs tell: truly he hath never a beard.

sp.speaker: Old Lord.
sp.p: Indeed a man should have a beard. Well mistress correction, your husband must have you back again :
sp.l: And thus in friendship ends long Jealous strife,
With all things well, save Wages wants a wife.
But Gentlemen, whose judgments sit
in strict commission on the wit:
Which from the Authors pen did flow
He wisheth at all but this to know.
that if you well do censure him,
He ready is with brains and pen,
Another time to pleasure you,
If not, he bids you all adieu.
For well he knows he hath done well ,
And so he boldly dares to tell.
Yet for the children ere I go,
Your censure I would willing know.
For if you do the Action blame.
They ready are with pardon drawn
And each of them here hoping stands
That you will sign it with your hands.
